revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2018}} {{more citations needed|date=February 2016}} {{infobox person |name=Abul Kashem Khan |image=Ayub Khan & A K Khan.jpg |caption= General [[Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)|Ayub Khan]] at the residence of Khan (right) in [[Chittagong]] (1960) |birth_date={{birth date|1905|4|5|df=y}} |birth_place= Mohara village, Panchlaish Thana, [[Eastern Bengal and Assam]], [[British India]] |nationality=Bangladeshi |death_date={{death date and age|1991|3|31|1905|4|5|df=y}} |occupation=Industrialist }} '''Abul Kashem Khan''' (best known as '''A. K. Khan'''; 5 April 1905 – 31 March 1991) was a [[Pashtuns|Pashtun]]-[[Bangladeshi]] lawyer, industrialist and politician. In 1945, he founded [[A K Khan & Company]], one of Pakistan's leading [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerates]] until 1971, when it became one of Bangladesh's leading conglomerates.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|last1=Islam|first1=Sirajul|title=Khan, Abul Kashem|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Khan,_Abul_Kashem|website=banglapedia|accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> Khan served as a member of the [[Constituent Assembly of India]] and the [[Constituent Assembly of Pakistan]]. He was a federal minister of [[Pakistan]] and member in the [[Pakistan National Assembly]].
== Early life == Khan was born in the Village of Mohara in [[Panchlaish Thana|Panchlaish]] in [[Chittagong]] in 1905. His father was a government sub-registrar at Fatehabad, Chittagong. He studied law at [[Presidency University, Kolkata|Presidency College]], [[Calcutta]]. In 1934 he joined the Kolkata High court as an advocate. He joined the judicial branch of the Bengali Civil service in 1935. He continued in the service till 1944.<ref name=":0"/>
== Career == Khan entered business during the [[Second World War]] in 1945, when Chittagong was a key base for Allied Forces. He step up a number of industries including a match factory, a plywood factory, a textile mill, and dockyard. He was elected a member of the Constituent Assembly of India from the [[All-India Muslim League]] candidate in 1946. He joined the Pakistan Constituent Assembly after the partition of India. In 1951-1952 budget he spoke against the economical discrimination of East Pakistan.<ref name=":0"/>
''"Sir, I cannot help' remark ' which I hope will not be misinterpreted as an indication of petty provincial-mindedness. Sir, these are the days of decentralisation and regional self-sufficiency. We find that in this six-year plan, the total sum allocated to East Bengal where 56 percent of your people live is less than 23 percent. Under the head 'Agriculture', provision has been made for 82 crores and a sum total of all the projects envisaged for East Bengal is only 5.6 crores. Under the head 'Development of Hydro-Electric Power', a provision for 45 crores has been made and the share of East Bengal is only 5 crores. Under the head 'Industries', provision has been made for textile industries' [for West Pakistan] to the tune of 30 crores and the provision for jute industry' [for East Bengal] is only 11 crores. Now, Sir, this gives a clear indication that not only in the past, not only in the present, but in the future development plans of the country, East Bengal is not expected to get its legitimate share."''<ref name=":0"/><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Szfqq7ruqWgC|title=Bangladesh: Past and Present|last=Ahmed|first=Salahuddin|date=2004-01-01|publisher=APH Publishing|isbn=9788176484695|page=337|language=en}}</ref>
He was the minister of Industries, Works, Irrigation, Power and Mineral Resources from 1958 to 1962. From 1962 to 1964 he was a member of the national assembly of Pakistan. He retired from politics in 1965.<ref name=":0"/>
== Death == He died on 31 March 1991.<ref name=":0"/>
==In popular culture== '''AK Khan More''' is a circle located in Chittagong, Bangladesh near Dhaka-Chittagong Trunk Road.
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Khan, Abul Kashem}} [[Category:Bangladeshi businesspeople]] [[Category:Bangladeshi lawyers]] [[Category:Bangladeshi politicians]] [[Category:1905 births]] [[Category:1991 deaths]] [[Category:People from Chittagong]] [[Category:Bengali Muslims]] [[Category:Bangladeshi Muslims]] [[Category:Members of the Constituent Assembly of India]] [[Category:Federal ministers of Pakistan]] [[Category:University of Calcutta alumni]] [[Category:Pakistan International Airlines people]] [[Category:20th-century Bangladeshi lawyers]] [[Category:Pakistani MNAs 1962–65]]

page.title: Anglo Irish Bank hidden loans controversy

revision.text:
{{for|this controversy in the wider context of the Irish banking crisis|Post-2008 Irish banking crisis}} {{use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} [[File:Protest against bailout of Anglo Irish Bank.jpg|300px|thumb|Protestors outside Anglo Irish Bank during protests against the bank bailout in April 2010]] The '''Anglo Irish Bank hidden loans controversy''' (also known as the '''circular transactions controversy''') began in Dublin in December 2008 when [[Seán FitzPatrick]], the chairman of [[Anglo Irish Bank]] (the state's third-largest bank), admitted he had hidden a total of [[Euro|€]]87 million in loans from the bank, triggering a series of incidents which led to the eventual [[Nationalization|nationalisation]] of Anglo on 21 January 2009. FitzPatrick subsequently resigned his position and was followed within twenty-four hours by the bank's non-executive director, [[Lar Bradshaw]] and chief executive, [[David Drumm]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2008/1219/anglo-business.html|title=Drumm quits Anglo in loans fall-out|date=19 December 2008|accessdate=19 December 2008|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}} A new chairman of Anglo, [[Donal O'Connor]], was quickly appointed from the board, a move welcomed by the Irish [[Minister for Finance (Ireland)|Minister for Finance]], [[Brian Lenihan Jnr|Brian Lenihan]]. A number of investigations have been launched into the reasons behind the three resignations. The [[Central Bank of Ireland]] is carrying out a review of the bank's dealings, although its [[Financial Regulator]], [[Patrick Neary]], has also since resigned his position. So too did a number of other chairmen, directors and executives involved with Anglo, [[Irish Life and Permanent]] and [[Irish Nationwide]]. Within days of the initial admission, an announcement was made that Anglo Irish Bank would be one of three (alongside [[Allied Irish Bank]] and [[Bank of Ireland]]) that would be recapitalised by the [[Irish government]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2008/1222/bank.html|title=Bank move a good deal for taxpayers: Lenihan|date=22 December 2008|accessdate=22 December 2008|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081222215745/http://www.rte.ie/news/2008/1222/bank.html|archivedate= 22 December 2008|deadurl= no}} The recapitalisation of Anglo Irish Bank was expected to be effected in mid-January 2009,{{cite web|url=http://www.financialregulator.ie/frame_main.asp?pg=%2Fnews%2Fnw%5Farticle%2Easp%3Fid%3D440&nv=%2Fnews%2Fnw%5Fnav%2Easp |title=Bank Government Announcement on Recapitalisation |date=21 December 2008 |accessdate=30 December 2008 |publisher=[[Financial Regulator]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129125817/http://www.financialregulator.ie/frame_main.asp?pg=%2Fnews%2Fnw_article.asp%3Fid%3D440&nv=%2Fnews%2Fnw_nav.asp |archivedate=29 January 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} following an [[Extraordinary General Meeting]] (EGM). Lenihan instead unexpectedly announced the nationalisation of Anglo Irish Bank the night before the EGM due to difficulties he encountered with the recapitalisation process. Recapitalisations of the other two banks mentioned were expected by the end of March 2009 but, according to [[Taoiseach]] [[Brian Cowen]], were expected to be finalised in early February 2009 at a total of €7 billion.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0207/economy.html|title=Bank recapitalisation finalised soon - Cowen|date=7 February 2009|accessdate=7 February 2009|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090208193317/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0207/economy.html|archivedate=8 February 2009| deadurl=no}} The nationalisation of Anglo Irish Bank on 21 January 2009 followed two more resignations earlier that month. On 7 January 2009, another director, [[Willie McAteer]], resigned, becoming the fourth casualty of the controversy. Two days later the Financial Regulator Patrick Neary retired amidst much criticism over his handling of the affair. After the nationalisation, the Chairman of Irish Nationwide, Dr Michael Walsh, resigned on 17 February, one week to the day that government-appointed directors announced they were investigating a deposit of billions of euro by Irish Life and Permanent, placed in Anglo Irish Bank before the end of its financial year.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0210/anglo-business.html|title=Anglo directors probe 'billions' deposit|date=10 February 2009|accessdate=10 February 2009|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}} Taoiseach Brian Cowen denied claims that he was protecting a "[[Anglo Irish Bank hidden loans controversy#The "Golden Circle"|Golden Circle]]" of wealthy financiers from being identified. This mysterious group of ten businessmen is said{{By whom|date=March 2011}} to have received loans from Anglo Irish Bank in return for buying shares, in a move designed to keep the bank afloat. ==Background== Starting in 1986, Seán "Seanie" FitzPatrick spent eighteen years as chief executive of Anglo Irish Bank, during which time the bank grew from a small operator into the third-largest bank in Ireland. When he became the bank's chairman in 2005, handing over the position of chief executive to David Drumm, the bank was recording annual profits of over €500 million. The Anglo share price peaked at €17.60 in May 2007, an increase from under €1 ten years previously. Anglo was valued at nearly €13 billion and FitzPatrick's 4.5 million Anglo shares were worth nearly €80 million at this time. Prior to FitzPatrick's resignation, the Anglo share price had already dropped to €0.32, a drop of 98% with the entire bank valued at a low €242 million and FitzPatrick's stake reduced to €1.5 million.{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/seanie-turned-a-struggling-minnow-into-a-banking-giant-1580520.html|title='Seanie' turned a struggling minnow into a banking giant|date=19 December 2008|accessdate=19 December 2008|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}} The Financial Regulator first uncovered the €87 million loans in January 2008 when inspectors from the regulator's offices carried out an inspection into the loan book of rival lender, [[Irish Nationwide Building Society]]. The inspectors noticed that a large loan was provided to FitzPatrick at Anglo Irish Bank and later repaid. The Regulator discovered at a later date that similar loans were provided to FitzPatrick in September 2008 and repaid by him in October 2008. When the issue was raised with Anglo Irish Bank it was discovered that there were further loans between the two banks over an extended period of eight years.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/finance/2008/1220/1229725700584.html|title=Regulator stumbled on loans during inspection of rival bank's books|date=20 December 2008|accessdate=20 December 2008|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}} It is uncertain which officials, if any, within the bank knew about the loans.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/finance/2008/1220/1229725700319.html?via=rel|title=Anglo stays silent over who knew of loans|date=20 December 2008|accessdate=20 December 2008|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}} Every Anglo annual report contained a note displaying the total loans given to directors of the bank. This total was measured at a single point in time. In the case of Anglo this occurred on 30 September. FitzPatrick, instead of revealing the true figures of his loans, transferred some of them to [[Irish Nationwide Building Society]], returning them to Anglo at a later date. He acted in a manner that thwarted transparency of Anglo's loan book. Financial authorities investigated if there were breaches of corporate governance. The Chief Executive of the Financial Regulator said that "a lay person would expect that issues of this nature and this magnitude would have been picked up" by the external auditors, [[Ernst & Young]].[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/frontpage/2009/0114/1231738222989.html FitzPatrick Anglo loans were more than €87m] After receiving legal advice Ernst & Young declined to appear before a parliamentary committee.{{cite news| url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0202/anglo-business.html|work=RTÉ News|title=Anglo auditors won't be at committee|date=2 February 2009}} This in turn led to inaccurate figures for the total directors' loans given for eight consecutive years in the end of year Anglo accounts. 2008 was the first occasion on which FitzPatrick revealed his true figure, that of €87 million or twice the total of the other twelve directors' loan figures.{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/why-directors-loans-fell-below-the-radar-1580570.html|title=Why directors' loans fell below the radar|date=19 December 2008|accessdate=19 December 2008|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''|first=Maeve|last=Dineen}} The situation was described as Ireland's version of [[Enron]], the American energy company which went bankrupt in 2001, and it was said that the principals would have been immediately arrested if this had occurred in the United States.[http://www.independent.ie/national-news/financial-crisis/if-fitzpatrick-lived-in-new-york-hed---have-been-arrested-1605179.html If FitzPatrick lived in New York, he'd have been arrested] == Resignations == === Anglo Irish Bank === FitzPatrick issued a statement on the evening of 18 December 2008, linking his resignation with a €87 million loan he had from the bank. Ireland's Minister for Finance, Brian Lenihan welcomed the appointment of a new chairman, Donal O'Connor, an official with a substantial commercial track record, saying he "seems a natural choice" for the role.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2008/1218/fitzpatricks.html|title=Chairman of Anglo Irish Bank resigns|date=18 December 2008|accessdate=19 December 2008|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081220080431/http://www.rte.ie/news/2008/1218/fitzpatricks.html|archivedate=20 December 2008|deadurl=no}} FitzPatrick's resignation came little over two months after he had admitted that his former bank had made mistakes but insisted it had not been "reckless".{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2008/1004/bank.html|title=Mistakes made says Anglo Irish Bank chairman|date=4 October 2008|accessdate=19 December 2008|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081223092341/http://www.rte.ie/news/2008/1004/bank.html|archivedate=23 December 2008|deadurl= no}} Alongside FitzPatrick's resignation came that of Bradshaw who had held a loan jointly with FitzPatrick, a loan that was temporarily transferred to another bank prior to a year end audit without the knowledge of Bradshaw.{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/anglo-chief-quits-after-hiding-euro87m--bank-loans-1580513.html|title=Anglo chief quits after hiding €87m bank loans|date=19 December 2008|accessdate=19 December 2008|publisher=Irish Independent|first1=Maeve|last1=Dineen|first2=Brendan|last2=Keenan|first3=John|last3=Mulligan}} On the evening of 19 December, Drumm announced he would step down with immediate effect, but said he will continue to work with the chairman through a transition phase until a replacement chief executive is agreed upon.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2008/1219/angloirish.html|title=Anglo Irish chief third to resign|date=19 December 2008|accessdate=19 December 2008|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081221123534/http://www.rte.ie/news/2008/1219/angloirish.html|archivedate=21 December 2008| deadurl= no}}
''It is appropriate for me to step down today given last evening's announcement in relation to the resignation of Seán FitzPatrick and given the strong statement of support for the Bank and its recapitalisation programme by the Minister for Finance. Good progress is being made on the recapitalisation. It is undoubtedly in the best interests of Anglo that a new Chief Executive is appointed to lead the Bank through its next phase of development. The appointment of Donal O'Connor as Chairman together with a new Chief Executive augurs well for the Bank and for all its stakeholders. It gives the Bank fresh impetus and an upward trajectory. I would like to thank all of my colleagues for their intense commitment and honest endeavour and for their friendship over the last 15 years.''{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2008/1219/breaking45.html?via=rel|title=Anglo Irish Bank statement on Drumm resignation|date=19 December 2008|accessdate=19 December 2008|publisher=''The Irish Times''}}
On 7 January 2009, Willie McAteer resigned his position as finance director and chief risk officer.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0107/anglo-business.html|title=Anglo Irish loses another director|date=7 January 2009|accessdate=7 January 2009|publisher=RTÉ}} On 15 January 2009 the Government of Ireland nationalised[http://www.independent.ie/national-news/taxpayer-is-picking-up--ailing-anglo-irish-bank-1603950.html Taxpayer is picking up ailing Anglo Irish Bank][http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/what-the-implications-are-for-savers-and-investors-as-state-takes-over-anglo-1603883.html What the implications are for savers and investors as State takes over Anglo] Anglo Irish Bank and its shares were suspended on the Dublin and London Stock Exchanges. On 19 January 2009, the balance[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0119/breaking19.html Anglo Irish directors step down, bank downgraded] of the Board, who had served while FitzPatrick was chairman, resigned. The consequence of Anglo's nationalisation caused steep[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0119/breaking36.htm Bank shares lose half their value in market 'carnage'] falls, up to 50%, in the market value of the other two large banks on 19 January 2009. ===Financial Regulator=== Following reports of a communication breakdown at the office of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority, the [[Financial Regulator]] Patrick Neary on 9 January 2009 announced his decision to retire as of 31 January that year.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0109/nearyp.html|title=Neary to retire as Financial Regulator|date=9 January 2009|accessdate=10 January 2009|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090111100225/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0109/nearyp.html|archivedate= 11 January 2009|deadurl=no}} Neary's weakness in dealing with the issue has received much criticism, with [[Green Party (Ireland)|Green Party]] Senator [[Dan Boyle (politician)|Dan Boyle]] calling for a strengthening of powers within the organisation and saying that confidence in Irish financial services had been eroded by events of the previous six months. Financial observers indicated that a replacement for Neary might have to be located in the United States or in Britain.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0110/finance.html|title=Greens call for stronger finance regulator|date=10 January 2009|accessdate=10 January 2009|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090110204138/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0110/finance.html| archivedate=10 January 2009|deadurl=no}} There were also reports that the Financial Regulator may have known of the loans for eight years prior to their revelation.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/finance/2009/0124/1232474679328.html?via=mr|title=Regulator may have known of loans to FitzPatrick for eight years|date=24 January 2009|accessdate=24 January 2009|publisher=''The Irish Times''}} The Fine Gael finance spokesman Richard Bruton called for the board and senior management of the Financial Regulator to be sacked.{{cite news| url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0222/breaking46.htm|work=The Irish Times|title=Financial Regulator board should be sacked|date=2 February 2009}} The Financial Regulator hired a partner from Ernst & Young, to advise on the €440 billion bank guarantee scheme in January 2009, despite the fact that serious questions have been asked about why Ernst & Young did not spot the massive loans that former chief executive Seán FitzPatrick concealed from his shareholders for eight years.{{cite web|url=http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2009/01/18/story38836.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090914154355/http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2009/01/18/story38836.asp |archivedate=14 September 2009 |df= }} Consultants [[Mazars]], which reviewed their operations said "that regulatory expertise was lacking in some areas."{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/top-watchdog-job-to-be-split-three-ways-in-regulatory-overhaul-1793401.html|work=Irish Independent|first=Joe|last=Brennan|title=Top watchdog job to be split three ways in regulatory overhaul|date=27 June 2009}} ===Irish Nationwide=== On the evening of 17 February 2009, the Chairman of the building society [[Irish Nationwide]], Dr Michael Walsh, resigned his position.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0217/irishnationwide.html|title=Irish Nationwide Chairman resigns|date=17 February 2009|accessdate=17 February 2009|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090219161741/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0217/irishnationwide.html|archivedate=19 February 2009|deadurl=no}} ===Irish Stock Exchange=== On 23 February 2009, the former Anglo Irish Bank director Anne Heraty unexpectedly resigned from the board of the [[Irish Stock Exchange|ISEQ]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0224/angloirish.html|title=Anglo Irish Bank offices were searched|date=24 February 2009|accessdate=24 February 2009|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090226193252/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0224/angloirish.html|archivedate=26 February 2009| deadurl=no}} The following morning, Dublin's ISEQ index fell over 3% to stand at 1,987, a 14-year low. The last time it stood under the 2,000 level was the middle of 1995.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0224/markets.html|title=ISEQ falls to 14-year low|date=24 February 2009|accessdate=24 February 2009|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090225033929/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0224/markets.html|archivedate=25 February 2009|deadurl=no}} ===Dublin Airport Authority=== On the evening of 24 February 2009, the chairman of the [[Dublin Airport Authority]] (DAA), [[Gary McGann]], announced his decision to step down from the board, stating that his decision had been influenced by his former non-executive directorship of Anglo Irish Bank.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0224/breaking76.htm|title=McGann steps down as chairman of DAA|date=24 February 2009|accessdate=24 February 2009|publisher=The Irish Times}} ==Outcome and nationalisation== Anglo Irish Bank has said it would review its policy on directors' loans following FitzPatrick's resignation. The [[Financial Regulator]] announced he would be examining the loans issued by Anglo Irish Bank to all its directors, claiming he became aware of the existence of the loans "following an inspection earlier this year". Ultimately he became a victim of the controversy and subsequently announced his retirement. The [[Chartered Accountants Regulatory Board]] (CARB) undertook an investigation into the "circumstances around the issue of inappropriate directors' loans at Anglo Irish"and into the performance of Ernst and Young.{{cite web|url=http://www.carb.ie/uploads/John%20Purcell%20Appointment.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090317220157/http://www.carb.ie/uploads/John%20Purcell%20Appointment.pdf |archivedate=17 March 2009 }} The [[Irish Association of Investment Managers]] expressed how it was "surprised and disappointed" at the controversy and announced it would be writing to Anglo's new chairman to describe its worries.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2008/1219/breaking13.html?via=mr|title=Drumm resigns as chief executive of Anglo Irish|date=19 December 2008|accessdate=19 December 2008|publisher=The Irish Times}} The Irish State subsequently announced it was to become the majority shareholder in Anglo Irish Bank by injecting €3 billion into the bank.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/frontpage/2008/1220/1229728408863.html?via=rel|title=State plans €3bn capital injection into Anglo Irish Bank|date=20 December 2008|accessdate=20 December 2008|publisher=The Irish Times}} Opposition party [[Fine Gael]] opposed this move and stated on 14 January 2009 that the bank should be shut down{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0114/banks.html|title=FG to oppose Anglo Irish recapitalisation|date=14 January 2009|accessdate=16 January 2009|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090115144251/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0114/banks.html|archivedate=15 January 2009}} but the following evening the Irish government announced that recapitalisation was no longer a serious option and nationalised the bank instead.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0115/banks.html|title=Govt to take control of Anglo Irish Bank|date=15 January 2009|accessdate=16 January 2009|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090116112513/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0115/banks.html|archivedate=16 January 2009}}[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/frontpage/2009/0116/1232059654021.html?via=rel Government nationalises 'fragile' Anglo Irish Bank] Lenihan stated that "clear blue water" had been inserted between the old and new versions of Anglo and defended the nationalisation by saying that if the government were to let the bank fail it would be saying to Ireland and other economies that the country was "closed for business".{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0116/anglo2-business.html|title=Lenihan defends Anglo takeover move|date=2009-01-16|accessdate=2009-01-16|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}} At an Emergency General Meeting held at the [[Mansion House, Dublin|Mansion House]], [[Dublin]] on 16 January 2009, the bank's shareholders angrily voiced their opinions on FitzPatrick's involvement in the bank's downfall and their lack of confidence in the banking sector. The auditors, Ernst & Young were also criticised for failing to detect the loans during their audits.{{cite news| url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0117/1232059657178.html|work=The Irish Times|title=Anglo's board and auditors criticised at egm Shareholders told FitzPatrick owed bank a total of €129m in 2007|date=1 January 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0116/banks.html|title=Shareholder anger at Anglo Irish meeting|date=16 January 2009|accessdate=16 January 2009|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117072556/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0116/banks.html|archivedate=17 January 2009}} At the EGM the total level of loans to directors was announced as €179 million.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0116/anglo-business.html|title=Anglo Irish directors' loans total €179m|date=16 January 2009|accessdate=16 January 2009|publisher=RTÉ}} ===Legislation=== {{further|Anglo Irish Bank Corporation Bill 2009}} Emergency legislation to nationalise the bank, titled the [[Anglo Irish Bank Corporation Bill 2009]], was voted through [[Dáil Éireann]], being approved by 79 – 67 before passing in [[Seanad Éireann]] without a vote on 20 January 2009. During the Seanad's debate on the bill, Senator [[Shane Ross]] claimed that "no-one was being told the truth about Anglo Irish Bank" and called the EGM of the previous Friday "a disgrace show[ing] corporate Ireland at its worst, as there were no answers to any questions". Senator [[Joe O'Toole]] advocated the chasing of those responsible for the bank's nationalisation "even into the courts", saying that a person could be imprisoned for failure to pay a household bill, yet those who caused the loss of jobs and pensions might not.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0120/angloirish.html|title=Dáil votes to nationalise Anglo Irish|date=20 January 2009|accessdate=21 January 2009|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203113936/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0120/angloirish.html|archivedate=3 February 2009|deadurl= no}} President Mary McAleese then signed the Anglo Irish Bank Bill at Áras an Uachtaráin the following day.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0121/angloirish.html|title=McAleese signs Anglo Irish Bank Bill|date=21 January 2009|accessdate=21 January 2009|publisher=RTÉ|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090124000047/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0121/angloirish.html|archivedate=24 January 2009| deadurl=no}} === Discussion === The bank's internal auditors appeared before the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Economic Regulatory Affairs on 3 February 2009 to discuss the nationalisation of [[Anglo Irish Bank]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0129/anglo-business.html|title=Anglo Irish auditors to be questioned|date=2009-01-29|accessdate=2009-02-05|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}} The bank's head of internal audit, Walter Tyrrell, told the Oireachtas committee that the movement of loans by Seán FitzPatrick into the bank and back out again could only have been known by FitzPatrick himself and the executive of his account, claiming that loans were tested by means of random sampling and that FitzPatrick's loans had not once been selected - however one loan he held with a partner was chosen. Fine Gael's [[Kieran O'Donnell]] expressed his amazement that each of the directors' loans were not tested.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0203/anglo-business.html|title=Anglo director loans 'tested randomly'|date=2009-02-03|accessdate=2009-02-05|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}} On 11 February 2009, Lenihan revealed plans under which €3.5 billion ($4.5 billion, £3.1 billion) each would be provided by the government's purchase of [[Option (finance)#Long call|options]] intended to re-capitalise Allied Irish Bank and the Bank of Ireland.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7884925.stm|title=Rescue plan for Ireland's banks|date=2009-02-12|accessdate=2009-02-12|publisher=[[BBC]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090213134314/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7884925.stm| archivedate= 13 February 2009 | deadurl= no}} == Findings == === Review === The Financial Regulator, on the recommendation of the Irish Finance Minister, ordered an "urgent review" of directors' loans at Anglo Irish Bank, saying it has a "very serious view" of the issue. It claimed the loans were "first brought to its attention on December 17th 2008" and that a committee had been established to investigate the matter. Irish [[Minister for Social Protection|Minister for Social and Family Affairs]] [[Mary Hanafin]] said the Financial Regulator had "serious questions" to answer over its supposed lack of knowledge of the loans and the Irish [[Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government|Minister for the Environment, Heritage and Local Government]] [[John Gormley]] asked the Financial Regulator to explain what he termed "extraordinary complacency" in relation to the situation at Anglo Irish Bank. The opposition party [[Fine Gael]]'s deputy leader and finance representative [[Richard Bruton]] quizzed the Minister for Finance on his announcement that he would provide the necessary capital to Anglo Irish Bank.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2008/1220/breaking24.htm|title=IFSRA board orders urgent review into Anglo loans|date=2008-12-20|accessdate=2008-12-20|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}} === Further Hidden Loans (Deposits) Controversy Involving Irish Life & Permanent === On 12 February 2009, details of a further controversial transaction which had the effect of misrepresenting the end-of-year accounts of Anglo-Irish Bank came into the public domain. Anglo-Irish Bank lent €4bn to Irish Life & Permanent (IL&P) for 1 day by way of inter-bank loan, and a subsidiary of Irish Life placed a deposit of a similar amount with Anglo, which was recorded as a customer deposit. Following a discussion with the Minister for Finance, a board meeting of IL&P accepted the resignation of two senior IL&P executives.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0213/breaking12.html?via=rel|title=Statement by Irish Life & Permanent|date=2009-02-13|accessdate=2009-02-13|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}} === The "Golden Circle" === On 17 February, Taoiseach Brian Cowen informed Dáil Éireann of his knowledge of a group of ten wealthy businessmen who had come together to buy shares in Anglo Irish Bank in 2008 in a transaction which is now at the centre of an investigation by the Office of Corporate Enforcement.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0217/angloirish.html|title=Anglo share purchases raised in Dáil|date=2009-02-17|accessdate=2009-02-18|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090218130912/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0217/angloirish.html| archivedate= 18 February 2009 | deadurl= no}} Cowen has since denied suggestions put forth by the Opposition that he was attempting to protect anyone involved in this so-called "Golden Circle".{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0218/banks.html|title='Golden Circle' dominates Dáil proceedings|date=2009-02-18|accessdate=2009-02-18|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090219201336/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0218/banks.html| archivedate= 19 February 2009 | deadurl= no}} The mystery has been discussed in Dáil Éireann since its revelation, with Minister for the Environment, Community and Local Government and [[Green Party (Ireland)|Green Party]] leader [[John Gormley]] calling for the names to be made public if a legal way of doing so could be found.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0219/angloirish.html|title=Golden Circle names should be public - Gormley|date=2009-02-19|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090221035523/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0219/angloirish.html| archivedate= 21 February 2009 | deadurl= no}} Anglo Irish Bank's annual report alongside the PricewaterhouseCooper report on the bank were both published on 20 February but [[Tánaiste]] [[Mary Coughlan (politician)|Mary Coughlan]] stated beforehand that the ten would not be named in either report. The Anglo report revealed that the bank lent €451 million to the ten "Golden Circle" clients, a 50% increase on previous estimates of €300 million.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0220/breaking14.html?via=mr|title=Anglo loaned €451m to 10 clients to buy bank shares|date=2009-02-20|accessdate=2009-02-20|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}} That same evening, Brian Lenihan also issued a statement containing extracts from the report carried out by PricewaterhouseCooper for the Financial Regulator.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0220/breaking86.htm|title=Lenihan statement on the PWC report|date=2009-02-20|accessdate=2009-02-20|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}} The morning before its publication, [[Ulick McEvaddy]] appeared on [[RTÉ Radio 1]] alongside the [[Socialist Party (Ireland)|Socialist Party]]'s [[Joe Higgins]], where he stated that the ten were "heroes" in his opinion (Joe Higgins disagreed).{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0220/banks.html |title=McEvaddy praises Golden Circle 'heroes' |date=2009-02-20 |accessdate=2009-02-20 |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224073335/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0220/banks.html |archivedate=24 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} {{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0220/breaking43.htm|title=McEvaddy defends Anglo Irish investor 'heroes'|date=2009-02-20|accessdate=2009-02-20|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}} ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' published the names of four of the Golden Circle members on 22 February.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0222/anglo.html|title=Four 'Golden Circle' named by newspaper|date=2009-02-22|accessdate=2009-02-22|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090226105556/http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0222/anglo.html| archivedate= 26 February 2009 | deadurl= no}} The four members of the elite are [[Gerry Gannon]], [[Joe O'Reilly (builder)|Joe O'Reilly]], Seamus Ross and [[Jerry Conlan]]. The same article declared that [[Sean Mulryan]], [[Patrick Doherty]], [[Seán Dunne (businessman)|Sean Dunne]], [[Derek Quinlan]], [[Denis O'Brien]], [[JP McManus]], [[John Magnier]], [[Noel Smyth]], [[Michael Whelan]], [[Jim Mansfield]], Richard Barrett, [[Johnny Ronan]] and [[Fintan Drury]] were not among the chosen ten.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/ireland/article5781014.ece|title=Named: four of Anglo's 'golden circle' – Gerry Gannon, Joe O'Reilly, Seamus Ross and Jerry Conlan are four of the businessmen who secretly bought 10% of Anglo Irish Bank with the bank's own cash|date=2009-02-22|accessdate=2009-02-22|publisher=''[[The Sunday Times]]'' | location=London | first=Tom | last=Lyons}} Minister [[Dick Roche]] has since stated that the ten cannot be named.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0223/breaking58.html?via=mr|title='Golden Circle' cannot be named, claims Roche|date=2009-02-24|accessdate=2009-02-24|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}} On 23 July 2012 the Irish Independent identified the ten members of the golden circle as Belfast-born developer Paddy McKillen, Mennolly Homes's Seamus Ross, auctioneer Brian O'Farrell, John McCabe of McCabe Builders, developer Gerry Maguire, Belfast's Patrick Kearney, Gerry Gannon of Gannon Homes who had a stake in the K Club Ryder Cup golf resort, Kildare businessman Jerry Conlan, Sean Reilly of the McGarrell Reilly firm and developer Joe O'Reilly.{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/two-former-anglo-executives-charged-with-fraud-offences-3177514.html | work=Irish Independent | title=Two former Anglo executives charged with fraud offences | date=2 December 2012}} === Fraud search === On 24 February 2009, members of the [[Garda Bureau of Fraud Investigation]] executed a [[District Court (Ireland)|District Court]] warrant at the headquarters of Anglo Irish Bank on [[St Stephen's Green]], [[Dublin]]. The warrant, issued the previous day, allowed the Gardaí, acting on behalf of the Office of the [[Director of Corporate Enforcement]], to enter the premises and seize documents that may show crimes committed under section 20 of the Companies' Acts.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/feb/24/anglo-irish-bank-banking|title='Police raid Anglo Irish|date=2009-02-24|accessdate=2009-02-24|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|first=Henry|last=McDonald|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090227075924/http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2009/feb/24/anglo-irish-bank-banking|archivedate=27 February 2009|deadurl=no}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7907926.stm|title=Fraud search at Anglo Irish Bank|date=2009-02-24|accessdate=2009-02-24|publisher=[[BBC]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090225112215/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7907926.stm|archivedate=25 February 2009|deadurl=no}} == See also == * [[List of Irish companies]] * [[FÁS expenses scandal]] * [[Enten controversy]] * [[Put on the green jersey]] == References == {{Reflist|33em}} == External links == * [http://www.angloirishbank.ie/ Anglo Irish Bank] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071230224014/http://www.financialregulator.ie/ Financial Regulator] * [http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0219/rteieextraaudio_av.html?2494843,null,209 Audio of Ulick McEvaddy and Joe Higgins's "Golden Circle" Clash] on [[RTÉ Radio 1]] – 20 February 2009 {{Corporate scandals}} {{2008 economic crisis|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Post-2008 Irish economic downturn]] [[Category:2008 in Irish politics]] [[Category:2009 in Irish politics]] [[Category:Accounting scandals]] [[Category:Banking in Ireland]] [[Category:Financial regulation]] [[Category:Anglo Irish Bank]] [[Category:Banking controversies]]

'''Antonio Juan Marcos Issa''' (born October 26, 1946; [[Torreón]], [[Coahuila]]) is a businessman of Mexico.
== Life == He studied Economics in [[University of Nuevo León]], graduated in 1969. Also, he has a [[master degree]] in Economic Planning in the [[New School for Social Research]] in New York City.
He has been professor in the Economics Faculty of the [[University of Nuevo León]]; lecturer in the Economics School of the [[Instituto Tecnológico Autónomo de México]]; was director of Economic Studies Department of the [[Instituto Mexicano de Comercio Exterior]].
As a public servant, between 1973 and 1977 occupied the Subdirection of Industrial Production in the Mexican Institute of Coffee (Inmecafé), after that until 1980 was chief director of Fondo Nacional para Actividades Sociales (FONAPAS). Ambassador of Mexico in the [[FAO]] during two years from 1980 to 1982,<ref>FAO [http://www.fao.org/docrep/meeting/011/ag405e/ag405e06.htm Delegates and Observers]. ''Report of the Council of FAO.'' Office of Knowledge Exchange, Research and Extension. Rome. November 26, 1981.</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Martínez Gómez|first1=Francisco |title=La globalización en la agricultura|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=w5x6km6xbFQC&printsec=frontcover&hl=es&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate= April 1, 2013|language=Spanish |edition= 1st|year=2002 |editor= Universidad Autónoma Agraria Antonio Narro|publisher=Plaza y Valdés|isbn=9707221062|pages=77}}</ref>
He was also representative of [[Pemex]] Europe at its head office in [[Paris]], [[France]] between 1983 and 1986. At the [[Secretariat of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)|Secretariat of Foreign Affairs]] he worked as regional director till 1993. He was Director of Finances of [[Coahuila|Coahuila state]] during 6 years. General advisory in General Direction of Pemex from 2000 to February 2003.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Berrueto González |first1=Arturo |title=Nuevo Diccionario Biográfico de Coahuila 1550-2005 |url= |language=Spanish|edition= 2nd|year=2005 |publisher= Gobierno del Estado de Coahuila |place=Saltillo |isbn=9789687568287 |page=710 }}</ref>
As a businessman, he has participated in the agricultural and construction businesses since 1985, currently has investments in energy.

{{Infobox person | name = Bart Decrem | image = BartDecrem.jpg | alt = | caption = Bart Decrem in 2015 | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Belgium]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = SVP and General Manager, Mobile Games, at [[The Walt Disney Company]] (July 2010 - July 2013),
Founder and CEO [[Tapulous]],
Entrepreneur In Residence DCM,
Founder and CEO [[Flock, Inc.|Flock]], Inc,
Head of marketing, business affairs [[Mozilla]] Foundation,
Co-Founder [[Eazel]],
Founder and Executive Director [[Plugged In]] | known_for = }} '''Bart Decrem''' is a Silicon Valley entrepreneur who, most recently, headed the Mobile Games business for [[The Walt Disney Company]] between July 2010 and the Fall of 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/1269265/billboard-qa-tapulous-co-founder-Decrem-decrem | title=Billboard Q&A: Tapulous Co-Founder Bart Decrem|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref> He was born and raised in [[Belgium]].
== Early life == His first entrepreneurial venture was at the age of 13, when he started a weekly magazine for Belgium’s leading underground radio station while working as a DJ there. Decrem moved to the US to study law at Stanford University. After graduation, Decrem founded Plugged In, a non-profit organization in East Palo Alto that provided community members with Internet access and related educational programs. Plugged In was one of the first such Digital Divide programs in the United States.
== Career == In 1999, Decrem co-founded [[Eazel]], an open source [[Linux]] desktop start-up. Their software, Nautilus, continues to be popular among Linux users. Among other projects, he coordinated the creation of the [[GNOME Foundation]]. After Eazel shut down in 2001, Decrem spent 18 months in Seoul, doing business development for several local startups.
In 2003-2004, Decrem headed marketing and business affairs for the [[Mozilla Foundation]]. He coordinated [[Firefox]] marketing activities, including branding, the Firefox 1.0 launch and the creation of Spread Firefox, the community marketing effort for Firefox. He also headed up partnerships with [[Google]], [[Yahoo]], [[Amazon Basin|Amazon]] and [[Mozilla]]. His work for Mozilla was sponsored by [[Mitch Kapor]]’s Open Source Applications Foundation.
After leaving Mozilla, he started [[Flock, Inc.|Flock]], a startup building a social web browser.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2005/10/24/new-social-web-browser-based-on-firefox | title=New 'Social' Web Browser Based on Firefox|work=[[FoxNews]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.infoworld.com/t/applications/flock-founder-hopes-new-browser-will-fly-users-752 | title=Flock founder hopes new browser will fly with users|work=[[InfoWorld]]}}</ref> Angel investors in Flock included [[Josh Kopelman]], [[Gil Penchina]], [[Joe Kraus]], [[Scott Kurnit]], [[Stratton Sclavos]] and others. VC investors included [[Bessemer Venture Partners]], Catamount Ventures and Shasta Ventures. He was Flock’s CEO through its Series C, and left the company in the Summer of 2006.
In 2007, Decrem worked as an Entrepreneur In Residence at DCM (Doll Capital Management).
In January, 2008, Bart Decrem was Founder and CEO at [[Tapulous]], one of the first iPhone startups. [[Andrew Lacy]] was the Co-Founder at [[Tapulous]]. Tapulous is the company behind [[Tap Tap Revenge]] one of the first major game hits on the App Store.
In April, 2009, [[comScore]] announced that Tap Tap Revenge was the most popular App Store app of all times on the occasion on Apple’s announcement of the first one billion app downloads. At that time, according to comScore, Tap Tap Revenge was installed on 32% of all iPhones in the United States of America.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/22/technology/start-ups/22tap.html | title=Music Games for iPhone Give Artists New Spotlight| work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://ir.comscore.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=375787 | title=Top 25 All-Time iPhone Apps Mostly Games| work=[[ComScore]]}}</ref>
In July, 2010 Tapulous was acquired by The Walt Disney Company.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2010/07/02/disney-buys-tapulous-to-drive-mobile-strategy/?_r=0| title=Disney Buys Tapulous to Drive Mobile Strategy| work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
From July 2010 until June 2013 he was SVP and General Manager for Disney Mobile Games,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/velocity/2010/07/01/iphone-game-studio-tapulous-has-been-acquired-by-disney | title=Iphone game studio Tapulous has been acquired by Disney|work=[[Forbes]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/03/14/bart-decrem-on-how-to-stay-lean-and-mean-in-mobile-gaming-even-when-youre-a-part-of-disney | title=Bart Decrem on how to stay lean and mean in mobile gaming even when you're a part of Disney|work=[[TechCrunch]]}}</ref> the group behind the smartphone hits Where’s My Water, Temple Run: Oz and Where’s My Mickey.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.ro/Lectii-despre-jocurile-pentru-dispozitive-mobile-de-la-vice-presedintele-disney_0_9236.html | title=Lessons on games for mobile devices from the Vice President of Disney |work=forbes.ro}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.tijd.be/siliconvalley/2013/09/bart-decrem-king-of-the-app-store.html | title= Bart Decrem King of the App Store|work=tijd.be}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.webster.edu/business-and-technology/news-and-events/speaker-series/bart-decrem.html |title=Bart Decrem at Webster University |work=webster.edu |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140112090945/http://www.webster.edu/business-and-technology/news-and-events/speaker-series/bart-decrem.html |archivedate=2014-01-12 |df= }}</ref>
Decrem was recognized as one of the fifty most creative people in business in 2009 by [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1651696/most-creative-entrepreneurs-business | title=Most Creative Entrepreneurs Business|work=[[FastCompany]]}}</ref> and one of the 10 most creative people in the Music Biz by [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1290830/10-most-creative-people-music-biz | title=10 Most Creative people Music Biz|work=[[FastCompany]]}}</ref> He has also been featured in Advertising Age's "2010 Creativity 50" by [[Creativity (magazine)|FastCompany]]}}</ref> He has also been featured in Advertising Age's "2010 Creativity 50" by [[Creativity]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://creativity-online.com/news/the-2010-creativity-50/142647 | title=The 2010 Creativity 50 |work=[[Creativity (magazine)|Creativity]]}}</ref>

{{Infobox musical artist |name = Berry Gordy |background = non_performing_personnel |image = Berry Gordy.jpg |birth_name = Berry Gordy III |alias = Berry Gordy Jr. |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1929|11|28}} |birth_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], U.S. |genre = {{hlist|[[Rhythm and blues|R&B]]|[[Soul music|soul]]|[[Pop music|pop]]|[[rock and roll]]|[[doo-wop]]}} |occupation = {{hlist|Record executive|record producer|songwriter|film producer|television producer}} |years_active = 1957–present |label = [[Motown]] |associated_acts = {{hlist|[[The Jackson 5]]|[[The Corporation (record production team)|the Corporation]]|[[Diana Ross & the Supremes]]|[[Smokey Robinson]]|[[the Temptations]]|[[Stevie Wonder]]|[[the Four Tops]]|[[the Miracles]]|[[Marvin Gaye]]|[[Jackie Wilson]]|[[Martha and the Vandellas]]|[[Rockwell (musician)|Rockwell]]}} }} '''Berry Gordy III'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0330700/bio|title=Berry Gordy|website=IMDb}}</ref> (known professionally as '''Berry Gordy Jr.''',<ref name="Bayles">{{cite book|url=http://www.alex-haley.com/movin_up_pop_gordy_tells_his_story.htm|title=Movin' Up – Pop Gordy Tells His Story|last=Gordy|first=Berry Sr.|publisher=Harper Collins|year=1979|isbn=0060220538}}</ref> born November 28, 1929) is an American record executive, record producer, songwriter, film producer and television producer. He is best known as the founder of the [[Motown]] record label and its subsidiaries, which was the highest-earning [[African-American businesses|African-American business]] for decades.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-VYN_LWZwf4C&pg=PA346&lpg=PA346&dq=most+lucrative+african+american+business+motown&source=bl&ots=GK_2XhqLfq&sig=HtIHRshAwnjQuDB9pWkffgwBZ6Y&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjlhNrYyL3QAhUE7SYKHfWZBF0Q6AEIMjAC#v=onepage&q=most%20lucrative%20african%20american%20business%20motown&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of African American Business|last=Smith|first=Jessie Carney|date=2006-01-01|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780313331107|language=en}}</ref>
==Early years== Berry Gordy III (also known as Berry Gordy Jr.) was <!--the seventh of eight children (Fuller, [[Esther Gordy Edwards|Esther]], [[Anna Gordy Gaye|Anna]], Loucye, George, [[Gwen Gordy Fuqua|Gwen]], ''Berry'' and [[Robert Gordy|Robert]]),--> born on November 28, 1929<ref name=biography>[http://www.biography.com/people/berry-gordy-jr-9316017 Berry Gordy Jr. Biography, ''Biography.com'']</ref> in Detroit, to the middle-class [[Gordy family|family of Berry Gordy II]] (also known as Berry Gordy Sr.), who had relocated to Detroit from [[Oconee, Georgia|Oconee]] in Washington County, Georgia, in 1922.<ref name="Bayles" /> The first Berry Gordy was the son of a white plantation owner, James Gordy, in Georgia and his female slave. His half-brother, James, was the grandfather of President [[Jimmy Carter]]. Berry Gordy II was lured to Detroit by the job opportunities for black people offered by the booming automotive businesses.<ref name="Bayles" /> <!--Berry dropped out of high school in the eleventh grade to become a professional [[boxing|boxer]] in hopes of becoming rich quick,{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} a career he followed until 1950, when he was drafted by the [[United States Army]] for service in the [[Korean War]]. Arriving in Korea in May 1952, Gordy was first assigned to the 58th Field Artillery Bn., 3rd Inf. Div., near Panmunjom. He later became a chaplain’s assistant, driving a jeep and playing the organ at religious services at the front. His tour in the Korean War was completed in April 1953.
After his return from Korea in 1953, he married Thelma Coleman.-->Gordy Jr. developed his interest in music by writing songs and opening the 3-D Record Mart, a record store featuring jazz music and 3-D glasses.<ref name=DesertIsland>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07bt72r |title=BBC Radio 4 - Desert Island Discs, Berry Gordy |author=BBC |date=22 May 2016 |access-date=25 May 2016 |quote=I was heavily into Jazz and so I opened up this Jazz record store, and in Detroit the people that came in there were asking for the Blues}}</ref> The store was unsuccessful, and Gordy sought work at the [[Lincoln-Mercury]] plant, but his family connections put him in touch with Al Green (no relation to the singer Reverend [[Al Green]]), owner of the Flame Show Bar Talent Club, where he met the singer [[Jackie Wilson]].{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
In 1957 Wilson recorded "[[Reet Petite]]", a song Gordy had co-written with his sister Gwen and writer-producer [[Billy Davis (songwriter)|Billy Davis]]. It became a modest hit, but had more success internationally, especially in the UK, where it reached the Top 10 and even later topped the chart on re-issue in 1986. Wilson recorded six more songs co-written by Gordy over the next two years, including "[[Lonely Teardrops]]", which topped the R&B charts and got to number 7 in the pop chart. Berry and Gwen Gordy also wrote "[[All I Could Do Was Cry]]" for [[Etta James]] at [[Chess Records]].{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
==Motown Record Corporation== {{main|Motown}}
Gordy reinvested the profits from his songwriting success into producing. In 1957, he discovered [[the Miracles]] (originally known as the Matadors) and began building a portfolio of successful artists. In 1959, with the encouragement of Miracles leader [[Smokey Robinson]], Gordy borrowed $800 from his family to create an R&B record company. Originally, Gordy wanted to name the new label Tammy Records, after [[Tammy (song)|the song]] recorded by [[Debbie Reynolds]]. However, that name was taken, and he chose the name [[Tamla Records]]. The company began operating on January 21, 1959. "Come to Me" by Marv Johnson was issued as Tamla 101. [[United Artists Records]] picked up "Come to Me" for national distribution, as well as Johnson's more successful follow-up records such as "[[You Got What It Takes]]", co-produced by Gordy, who also received a co-writer credit, though the song was originally written and recorded by guitarist [[Bobby Parker (guitarist)|Bobby Parker]] for Vee Jay records a year and a half earlier. Gordy's next release was the only 45 ever issued on his Rayber label, featuring Wade Jones with an unnamed female backup group. The record did not sell well and is now one of the rarest issues from the Motown stable. Berry's third release was "[[Bad Girl (The Miracles song)|Bad Girl]]" by [[the Miracles]], the first release on the Motown record label. "Bad Girl" was a solid hit in 1959 after [[Chess Records]] picked it up. [[Barrett Strong]]'s "[[Money (That's What I Want)]]" initially appeared on Tamla and then charted on Gordy's sister's label, [[Anna Records]], in February 1960. It was The Miracles who gave the label its first million-selling hit single, with the 1960 ''[[Grammy Hall of Fame]]'' smash, "[[Shop Around]]" and this song, and its follow up hits,"[[You've Really Got a Hold on Me]]" (another ''Grammy Hall of Fame''-inducted hit), "[[Mickey's Monkey (song)|Mickey's Monkey]]","[[What's So Good About Goodbye]]", and "[[I'll Try Something New (song)|I'll Try Something New]]", made The Miracles the label's first stars.
The Tamla and Motown labels were then merged into a new company, [[Motown|Motown Record Corporation]], incorporated on April 14, 1960. In 1960, Gordy signed an unknown singer, [[Mary Wells]], who became the fledgling label's second star, with Smokey Robinson penning her hits "[[You Beat Me to the Punch]]", "[[Two Lovers (Mary Wells song)|Two Lovers]]", and "[[My Guy]]". The Miracles' hit "[[Shop Around]]" peaked at No. 1 on the national [[R&B]] charts in late 1960 and at No. 2 on the ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]'' pop charts on January 16, 1961 (No. 1 pop, [[Cashbox (magazine)|Cash Box]]), which established Motown as an independent company worthy of notice. Later in 1961, [[the Marvelettes]]' "[[Please Mr. Postman]]" made it to the top of both charts. [[File:Berry Gordy House Boston Edison Detroit.JPG|thumb|Berry Gordy House, known as the Motown mansion, in Detroit's [[Boston-Edison Historic District]]<ref name=MotownMansion>{{cite web|url=http://motownmansion.com/ |title=Motownmansion.com |publisher=Motownmansion.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-30}}</ref>]]
Gordy's gift for identifying and bringing together musical talent, along with the careful management of his artists' public image, made Motown initially a major national and then international success. Over the next decade, he signed such artists as [[the Supremes]], [[Marvin Gaye]], [[the Temptations]], [[Jimmy Ruffin]], [[the Contours]], the [[Four Tops]], [[Gladys Knight & the Pips]], [[the Commodores]], [[the Velvelettes]], [[Martha and the Vandellas]], [[Stevie Wonder]] and [[the Jackson 5]]. Though he also signed various white acts on the label (Rare Earth, Rustix, via the Rare Earth label), he largely promoted African-American artists but carefully controlled their public image, dress, manners and choreography for across-the-board appeal.
==Relocation to Los Angeles== In 1972, Gordy relocated to Los Angeles, where he produced the commercially successful [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] on [[Billie Holiday]], ''[[Lady Sings the Blues (film)|Lady Sings the Blues]]'', starring [[Diana Ross]] (who was nominated for an [[Academy Award]]), [[Richard Pryor]], and [[Billy Dee Williams]] (cast in a role originally for [[Levi Stubbs]] of the [[Four Tops]]). Initially the studio, over Gordy's objections, rejected Williams after several screen tests. However, Gordy, known for his tenacity, eventually prevailed, and the film established Williams as a major movie star. Berry Gordy soon after produced and directed ''[[Mahogany (1975 film)|Mahogany]],''<ref>[[Tony Richardson]] was the original director, but Gordy fired Richardson and took over direction himself after a dispute over minor casting.</ref> also starring Ross and Williams. In 1985, he produced the cult martial arts film ''[[The Last Dragon]]'', which starred martial artist [[Taimak]] and one of [[Prince (musician)|Prince's]] proteges, [[Vanity (performer)|Vanity]].
Although Motown continued to produce major hits throughout the 1970s and 1980s by artists including the Jacksons, [[Rick James]], Commodores, [[Lionel Richie]] and long-term signings, Stevie Wonder and Smokey Robinson, the record company was no longer the major force it had been. Gordy sold his interests in Motown Records to [[Music Corporation of America|MCA]] and Boston Ventures on June 28, 1988, for $61 million. He later sold most of his interests in Jobete publishing to [[EMI]] Publishing. Gordy wrote or co-wrote 240 of the approximately 15,000 songs in Motown's Jobete music catalogue. However, the true test of the label's worth would come a few years later, when Polygram paid over $330 million ([[Diana Ross]] was given shares in this version of the label) for the Motown catalog.
Gordy published an autobiography, ''To Be Loved'', in 1994.
==Awards and accolades== Gordy was inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] in 1988.
Gordy was inducted into the Junior Achievement U.S. Business Hall of Fame in 1998.
In 2009, Berry Gordy was inducted into the Michigan Rock and Roll Legends Hall of Fame. <ref>https://www.michiganrockandrolllegends.com/mrrl-hall-of-fame/103-berry-gordy-jr</ref>
Gordy received the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]]'s Pioneer Award on June 13, 2013. He is the first living individual to receive the honor.<ref>Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/175832-Songwriters-Hall-of-Fame-to-Honor-Motowns-Berry-Gordy "Songwriters Hall of Fame to Honor ''Motown's'' Berry Gordy"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130407231259/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/175832-Songwriters-Hall-of-Fame-to-Honor-Motowns-Berry-Gordy |date=April 7, 2013 }} Playbill.com, March 12, 2013.</ref>
In 2016, Gordy received the [[National Medal of Arts]] from [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] for "helping to create a trailblazing new sound in American music. As a record producer and songwriter, he helped build Motown, launching the music careers of countless legendary artists. His unique sound helped shape our Nation's story."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/09/22/495011305/at-white-house-a-golden-moment-for-americas-great-artists-and-patrons|title=At White House, A Golden Moment For America's Great Artists And Patrons|publisher=}}</ref>
==Statements about Motown artists== Following the funeral of [[Marvin Gaye]] on April 5, 1984, Gordy declared Gaye "the greatest of his time" and stated the singer "had no musical equals", comparing his talents to those of [[Billie Holiday]].{{sfn|Ritz|1991|pp=336-337}}
On March 20, 2009, Gordy was in Hollywood to pay tribute to his first group and first million-selling act, [[the Miracles]], when the members received a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]. Speaking in tribute to the group, Gordy said: "Without the Miracles, Motown would not be the Motown it is today."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.daylife.com/photo/03Dy8rXgM6ctq?q=Pete+Moore |title=Photo from Reuters Pictures |publisher=Daylife.com |date=2009-03-20 |accessdate=2012-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318074101/http://www.daylife.com/photo/03Dy8rXgM6ctq?q=Pete+Moore |archivedate=2012-03-18 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zimbio.com/pictures/oyd__1s888I/Miracles+Honored+Hollywood+Walk+Fame/JrKAUKLXu0_ |title=The Miracles Honored At The Hollywood Walk Of Fame - Pictures |publisher=Zimbio |date=2009-03-20 |accessdate=2012-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zimbio.com/pictures/oyd__1s888I/Miracles+Honored+Hollywood+Walk+Fame/3UNMKXbcA5Z |title=The Miracles Honored At The Hollywood Walk Of Fame - Pictures |publisher=Zimbio |date=2009-03-20 |accessdate=2012-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zimbio.com/pictures/oyd__1s888I/Miracles+Honored+Hollywood+Walk+Fame/6cPIGmvSwSQ |title=The Miracles Honored At The Hollywood Walk Of Fame – Pictures |publisher=Zimbio |date=2009-03-20 |accessdate=2012-04-16}}</ref>
At the age of 79, Gordy spoke at the [[Michael Jackson memorial service|memorial service for Michael Jackson]] in Los Angeles, on July 7, 2009. He suggested that "The King of Pop" was perhaps not the best description for Jackson in light of his achievements, referring to him instead as "the greatest entertainer that ever lived."
==''Motown: The Musical''== On May 15, 2011, it was announced that Gordy was developing a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] musical about Motown. The show is said to be an account of events of the 1960s and how they shaped the creation of the label. Gordy hoped that the musical would improve the reputation of Motown Records and clear up any misconceptions regarding the label's demise.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://broadway.me/motown-founder-develops-own-story-for-broadway|title=Motown Founder Develops Own Story for Broadway|work=Broadway.me|accessdate=May 15, 2011}}</ref>
''[[Motown: The Musical]]'' began previews at the [[Lunt-Fontanne Theatre]] on March 11, 2013, and began regular performances there on April 14.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/earshot/berry-gordy-smokey-robinson-motown-musical-397503 | title=Berry Gordy, Doug Morris, Smokey Robinson Preview 'Motown: The Musical' | work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=December 4, 2012 | accessdate=December 24, 2012}}</ref> The musical closed in January 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/194792-Motown-Will-Move-Out-Musical-Will-Take-Broadway-Hiatus-With-UK-Plans-in-Store |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140822125003/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/194792-Motown-Will-Move-Out-Musical-Will-Take-Broadway-Hiatus-With-UK-Plans-in-Store |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 August 2014 |title=Motown Will Move Out! Musical Will Take Broadway Hiatus With U.K. Plans in Store |publisher=[[Playbill]] |work=playbill.com |date=21 August 2014 |accessdate=22 August 2014 }}</ref>
The UK version of Motown the Musical opened in the West End in January 2016. Berry Gordy went to the opening night.
==Personal life== Gordy, who was married and divorced three times, has eight children: Hazel Joy, Berry IV, Terry James, [[Kerry Gordy]], Sherry, [[Rockwell (musician)|Kennedy William]], [[Rhonda Ross Kendrick|Rhonda Suzanne]], and [[Redfoo|Stefan Kendal]]. His publishing company, Jobete, was named after his three eldest children, '''Jo'''y, '''Be'''rry and '''Te'''rry.
He had three children with his first wife, Thelma Coleman, whom he married in 1953 (they were divorced in 1959): * Hazel Joy (born August 24, 1954) * Berry IV (born October 1955) * Terry James (born August 1956)
His daughter Hazel was once married to [[Jermaine Jackson]]. His son Berry IV is father to [[Sky Blu (rapper)|Skyler Austen Gordy]]
In the spring of 1960 he married [[Ray Singleton|Raynoma Mayberry Liles]] (they were divorced in 1964).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soul-source.co.uk/_/soul-articles/shrine-the-full-and-first-issue-story-by-andy-rix-r309//|title=Shrine -The Full and first issue story by Andy Rix MISS RAY ARRIVES|date=|publisher=Soul Articles|accessdate=22 Feb 2001|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308192126/http://www.soul-source.co.uk/_/soul-articles/shrine-the-full-and-first-issue-story-by-andy-rix-r309|archivedate=2012-03-08|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Green |first=Michelle |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20113517,00.html |title=After Decades of Silence, Raynoma Singleton Is Singing the Blues About Her Ex-Husband Berry Gordy |publisher=People.com |date=1990-11-05 |accessdate=2012-04-16}}</ref> They had one child: * [[Kerry Gordy]] (born June 25, 1959)
With Jeana Jackson, Gordy had one daughter: * Sherry (born May 23 [1960?])<ref>{{cite web|last=Gordy|first=Sherry|title=Sherry Gordy's personal webpage|url=http://www.sherrygordy.com/Contact_Us.html|accessdate=22 December 2013}}</ref>
With his then-mistress Margaret Norton, Gordy had a son who would later become more popularly known as Motown musician [[Rockwell (musician)|Rockwell]]: * [[Rockwell (musician)|Kennedy William]] (born March 15, 1964)
Gordy had a daughter with Motown artist [[Diana Ross]], with whom he had an intimate relationship from 1965 through 1970: * [[Rhonda Ross Kendrick|Rhonda Suzanne]] (born August 14, 1971; her legal father is [[Robert Ellis Silberstein]] under California family law)
Gordy's eighth and youngest child is a son born to Nancy Leiviska. He is known by his stage name, [[Redfoo]], as one member of the duo [[LMFAO]] (the other member is Skyler Gordy, born August 23, 1986, and known professionally as [[SkyBlu]]; he is the grandson of Gordy and Thelma Coleman through their son Berry IV and his wife, Valerie Robeson): * [[Redfoo|Stefan Kendal]] (born September 3, 1975)
Berry married Grace Eaton on July 17, 1990; they divorced in 1993.
==Film== {|class="wikitable" |- align="center" ! Year ! Title ! Notes |- |1985 |''[[The Last Dragon]]'' | |}
===Broadway=== {|class="wikitable" |- align="center" ! Year ! Title ! Notes |- |1982 |''[[Rock 'N Roll! The First 5,000 Years]]'' |Writer: "[[I'll Be There (The Jackson 5 song)|I'll Be There]]" |- |2005 |''[[Lennon (musical)|Lennon]]'' |Writer: "[[Money (That's What I Want)]]" |- |2013 |''[[Motown: The Musical]]'' |Producer and writer, composer and lyricist |- |}
==In popular culture== * Gordy was portrayed by [[Billy Dee Williams]] (whose career Gordy had helped to jump-start in the 1970s) in the 1992 miniseries ''[[The Jacksons: An American Dream]]''. * Gordy was portrayed by [[Obba Babatunde]] in the 1998 miniseries ''[[The Temptations (TV miniseries)|The Temptations]]''. * The character Gordy Berry in ''[[The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air]]'' is a reference to Berry Gordy. * The character of Curtis Taylor Jr., a music executive in the 2006 musical film ''[[Dreamgirls (film)|Dreamgirls]]'', has been called "a thinly veiled portrayal" of Gordy.<ref name="sorry">[http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/they_re_berry_sorry_IyO4BBrykLSvrQo5kk6aHI THEY'RE BERRY SORRY], ''[[New York Post]]'', February 22, 2007</ref> The film was based on the 1981 musical ''[[Dreamgirls]]'', but the film made the connection to Gordy and Motown much more explicit than the musical did, by, among other things, moving the setting of the story from Chicago to Detroit. Taylor appears in the film as unethical and insensitive to his artists, which caused Gordy and others to criticize the film after its release. Gordy called the portrayal "100% wrong," while [[Smokey Robinson]] said it "blatantly painted a negative picture of Motown and Berry Gordy and of [[the Supremes]]."<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1355/is_11_111/ai_n27176841/ Berry Gordy speaks out on 'Dreamgirls'], ''[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]]'', March 19, 2007</ref> In 2007, the producers of the film, [[DreamWorks]] and [[Paramount Pictures]], issued a public apology to Gordy, saying they were sorry "for any confusion that has resulted from our fictional work." Gordy accepted the apology.<ref name="sorry" />

Melbourne, Florida | sister newspapers = Brevard Business News is an independent publication | oclc = 13920007 | ISSN = 0889-5104 | website = [http://www.brevardbusinessnews.com/ Brevard Business News] }} '''Brevard Business News''' is a weekly newspaper in [[Melbourne, Florida|Melbourne]], [[Florida]], [[United States]] covering business news and trends for the [[Space Coast]]. Fred Krupski started Brevard Business News in 1981,Mathers, Sandra. [http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1997-04-18/news/9704171131_1_krupski-darr-titusville "She Mastered World Of Weekly Newspapers"], ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'', April 18, 1997. Retrieved on May 26, 2011. and Adrienne B. Roth purchased it in 1986. ==Notes== {{coord|28|05|42.97|N|80|41|50.26|W|display=title|type:landmark}} [[Category:Companies based in Brevard County, Florida]] [[Category:American business newspapers]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Florida]] [[Category:1981 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Publications established in 1981]] {{florida-newspaper-stub}}
