page.title: Federation of Nepalese Chambers of Commerce and Industry

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Federation of Nepalese Chambers of Commerce and Industry | abbreviation = FNCCI | type = [[Chamber of Commerce and Industry|Business association]] | formation = {{start date and age|1965}} | status = [[Non-profit organization]] | foundation = 1965 | location_city = [[Kathmandu]] | location_country = [[Nepal]] | key_people = [[Bhawani Rana]]
([[President#Presidents_in_business|President]]) | num_staff = 60 | homepage = {{url|http://www.fncci.org/}} }} '''Federation of Nepalese Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FNCCI)''' is the umbrella organization of [[Nepal]]ese [[Chamber of commerce|Chambers of Commerce and Industry]]. It was established in 1965 with the aim of promoting business and industry while protecting the rights and interests of business and industrial communities FNCCI has been playing a key role in promoting business and industry in the country. It provides, inter alia, information, advisory, consultative, promotional and representative services to business and government and organises training / workshop / seminar on a regular basis. ==Organizational structure== The highest policy making body of the FNCCI is its General Assembly which generally meets on an annual basis. The activities and functions of the FNCCI are planned and managed by the Executive Committee consisting 74 members including President and 5 nominated members who have tenure of three years (As per the Fifth amendment of FNCCI Constitution). Immediate Past President is the ex-official member of this Committee. The Executive Committee elects Vice-Presidents and constitutes the Councils and various Committees and Forums. It also appoints Director General who heads the FNCCI Secretariat.{{cite web |url=http://fncci.org.np/intro.php |title=FNCCI Introduction |publisher=FNCCI |accessdate=30 December 2013}} ==Significance== FNCCI is the largest private sector organization in Nepal and has more than 10,000 direct and indirect members. Direct members are most big business houses and corporate companies of Nepal as well as few multinational companies that have production facilities in the country. FNCCI members consists Total of 104 District/Municipality Level Chamber of Commerce and Industry, 99 Commodity Associations, 12 Bi-National Chamber of Commerce and Industry and 799 Associate Members. FNCCI is working to promote Nepalese entrepreneurship and Nepalese products across the world. It maintains relations with the representative business associations of various countries of the world. FNCCI is continuously lobbying to strengthens the political framework conditions for a good business environment in the country.{{cite web |url=http://thehimalayantimes.com/fullNews.php?headline=FNCCI+team+meets+Koirala%26sbquo%3B+demand+economic+development+&NewsID=398069 |title=FNCCI team meets Koirala‚ demand economic development |date=29 November 2013 |publisher=The Himalayan Times |accessdate=28 December 2013}} ==Initiatives== FNCCI organizes among others Nepal International Trade Fair {{cite web |url=http://www.nepaltradefair.com/|title=Nepal Trade Fair Portal |publisher=FNCCI |accessdate=31 December 2013}} every year to promote Nepalese products across the globe. This trade fair is the biggest in the country and takes usually place in March or April. With the support of USAID, FNCCI established the Agro Enterprise Centre in 1991 which is promoting agro-business in the country. Within past fifteen years, FNCCI/AEC made valuable contributions in Agro Business Development and Promotion. Since 1 October 2002, FNCCI/AEC has been re-shaped with more focused Mission and Vision and is taking a renewed role in re-presenting the private sector agribusiness community in the development of agriculture and agribusiness in Nepal.{{cite web |url=http://www.aec-fncci.org/aboutus |title=Agro Enterprise Centre |publisher=FNCCI |accessdate=30 December 2013}} Due to regular power outage (called [[load shedding]]) up to 14 hours a day {{cite web |url=http://www.thehimalayantimes.com/fullNews.php?headline=Raju+Pandit+Chhetri&NewsID=322129 |title=Energy crisis |date=26 February 2012 |publisher=The Himalayan Times |accessdate=29 December 2013}} {{cite web |url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8789855-energy-crisis-leaves-nepal-in-the-dark |title=Energy crisis leaves Nepal in the dark |date=14 April 2011 |publisher=Surya Gaire |accessdate=29 December 2013}} and fuel shortage,{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/nepal-hit-hard-by-fuel-shortage/article1-687175.aspx |title=Nepal hit hard by fuel shortage |date=19 April 2011 |publisher=Hindustan Times |accessdate=29 December 2013}} Nepalese Industries are facing serious problems and severe production losses. Therefore, FNCCI established the [http://www.eec-fncci.org/ Energy Efficiency Centre (EEC)] in 2010 that is a think tank and service provider in the field of energy efficiency.{{cite web |url=http://www.eec-fncci.org/ |title=EEC Homepage |year=2012 |publisher=EEC |accessdate=30 December 2013}} The EEC is the first institution that is raising awareness for energy efficiency in Nepal's private sector and provides professional energy auditing services to the industries.{{cite web |url=http://eec-fncci.org/content-introduction |title=EEC Introduction |year=2012 |publisher=EEC |accessdate=30 December 2013}} Furthermore, FNCCI conducts various social activities like sport events, health camps etc. In 2012, FNCCI supported the CACCI-FNCCI Golf Challenge - an international golf competition in Nepal.{{cite web |url=http://www.kantipuronline.com/the-kathmandu-post/2012/10/04/related_articles/cacci-fncci-golf-challenge-on-saturday/240401.html |title=CACCI-FNCCI Golf Challenge on Saturday |date=5 October 2012 |publisher=The Kathmandu Post |accessdate=3 January 2013}} ==See also== *[[Economy of Nepal]] ==References== ==External links== * [http://fncci.org.np The Official Website of FNCCI] * [http://www.nepaltradefair.com/ Nepal Trade Fair] * [http://www.aec-fncci.org/ Agro Enterprise Centre] * [http://www.eec-fncci.org/ Energy Efficiency Centre] {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} [[Category:Business organisations based in Nepal]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1965]] [[Category:Chambers of commerce]]

{{notability|1=Biographies|date=July 2017}}
'''Gert Van Mol''' (born 1969) is a Belgian entrepreneur and CEO.
Van Mol was a student leader at the [[Université catholique de Louvain|Catholic University of Louvain]].<ref>{{cite web|title="In I.L.O. tempore". Verbeeld verleden van de Faculteit Bewegings- en ...|url=https://books.google.be/books?id=FDkwaKjigL4C&pg=PA148&lpg=PA148&dq=%22gert+van+mol%22+apolloon&source=bl&ots=T12tJQFRBj&sig=TxTuwB6MI1nVW3Sams4iAIZwrK0&hl=nl&ei=mwqNTqmMNYO6-AbpmcT5Cg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22gert%20van%20mol%22%20apolloon&f=false|work=google.be}}</ref> While studying he founded The Publishing Company, a publishing house, in 1990. Between 1990 and 2000 The Publishing Company initiated and published a series of youth magazines and books, such as TEEK magazine,<ref>{{cite web|title=Haalt Delhaize choquerende Teek weer uit haar rekken?|url=http://www.hbvl.be/Archief/guid/haalt-delhaize-choquerende-teek-weer-uit-haar-rekken.aspx?artikel=be294121-1450-11d5-8d37-0008c772a0e7|author=K.G.|work=Het Belang van Limburg}}</ref> the bestselling movie and music magazine in Flanders, as well as The Official PlayStation Magazine Benelux a Sony franchise, as well as IGLOO, Motel Flamingo, Bancoteek for [[KBC Bank]] and Impact magazine, the bestselling business youth magazine in Belgium.<ref>{{cite web|title=Teek start met zakentijdschrift.|url=http://www.loenochod.com/archive.php?id=89|work=loenochod.com}}</ref> The catchall term for all sorts of micro publishing "[[guerrilla publishing]]" was introduced by Van Mol. For publishing a series of religious books Van Mol received the Silver Cross "Arts, Sciences, Lettres" ([[Académie Française]], Paris)(2002). He also founded Filmbank, a chain of shops specialised in selling movie memorabilia in Belgium and The Netherlands.
In 2000 Van Mol sold his company to a company noted on the [[Euronext]] Stock Market.
==The Wall Street Journal== In 2002 Van Mol started to work for [[The Wall Street Journal]] where he founded The Wall Street Journal Future Leadership Institute, a virtual institute bridging university and industry.<ref>{{cite web|title=Diplomatie.be|url=http://www.diplomatie.be/london/media/london/be1110.pdf|work=diplomatie.be}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=LSE SU AIC - Media|url=http://www.lseaic.com/Partners/Media.aspx|work=lseaic.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Beyond the Sound Bite 2010 - Common Room @ CJBS|url=http://www.cr.jbs.cam.ac.uk/?page=AgendaMediaCBIGEvent|work=cam.ac.uk}}</ref> In 2012 The Wall Street Journal Future Leadership Institute became independent. Since 2012 it is called [[The Future Leadership Institute]]. The Future Leadership Institute operates worldwide organizing lunches, seminars and conferences always bringing student leaders and executives together around topics significant to society. The Future Leadership Institute is based in London.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of The Future Leadership Institute|url=https://fli.institute/history/}}</ref> For his work with the Institute Van Mol was awarded a Spanish medal, the [[Socio Distinguido de L'Agrupacion Espanole de Fomento Europea]] (Barcelona) and a French medal, the Silver Cross [[Encouragemant Public]] (Œuvre d’Entraide Sociale Française, Paris).
In 2005 Van Mol started the technology company Groep G publishing the first digital newspaper in Belgium following the birth of a son. Within the Groep new digital search technologies were developed making Van Mol a sought after speaker at universities and business schools.<ref>{{cite web|title=Van Mol speaking at The Oxford Cambridge Boat Race Seminar|url=http://www.rowingservice.com/WallStreetJ-BoatRace2010.doc}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Van Mol speaking at Knowledge Economy Network in Slovenia on the topic of One Laptop Per Child|url=http://videolectures.net/gert_van_mol/}}</ref>
==TV== In 2011 Van Mol was asked to become CEO/Crisis Manager of the TV station Life!TV Broadcasting Company, a digital TV station distributed via [[Telenet]], a subsidiary of [[Liberty Bell]]. In his capacity he introduced the first female presenter with a headscarf on Belgian TV. Van Mol’s life was threatened, although he also received great support by many groups in Belgian society.<ref>{{cite web|title=First woman with headscarf on Belgian TV|url=http://deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws/cultuur%2Ben%2Bmedia/media/1.1429961}}</ref> The TV station grew 600 percent in viewer participation between 2011 and 2013 upon which the station was sold.
==Giant Ferris Wheels== Between 2013 and 2015 Van Mol was CEO of Skyview in [[Amsterdam]], an entertainment company installing Giant Ferris Wheels all over the world. Van Mol initiated the installation of a Giant Ferris Wheel at the [[Scheveningen Pier]] in the Netherlands. The Giant Ferris Wheel of [[Scheveningen]] is the first 40-meter wheel that was built in the sea.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scheveningers bang voor inkijk door enorm reuzenrad|url=http://www.looopings.nl/weblog/3501/Scheveningers-bang-voor-inkijk-door-enorm-reuzenrad.htm}}</ref>
By mid 2015 Van Mol was asked to save the digital company foto.com by the family Grimaldi. The company was nearly bankrupt and was operating under [[Chapter 11]] conditions by the Court of Nivelles in Wallonia. Within the framework of the Court of [[Nivelles]] Van Mol succeeded in turning around the company upon which the Court freed the company from the Chapter 11 condition.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://fli.institute/ The Future Leadership Institute] * [http://www.impactroom.com/ Gert Van Mol Blog]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.internationalstudentsenate.blogspot.com/ International Student Senate] * [http://lifetv-41.blogspot.be/ Life!tv]

{{Infobox person | name = Grete Mosheim | image = Grete Mosheim's 1936 Hungarian passport photo.jpg | alt = Grete Mosheim's 1936 Hungarian passport photo | caption = Grete Mosheim's 1936 Hungarian passport photo | birth_name = Margarete Emma Dorothea Mosheim | birth_date = {{Birth date|1905|01|08|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Berlin]], Germany | death_date = {{Death date and age|1986|12|29|1905|01|08|df=yes}} | death_place = [[New York City]], US | nationality = German | other_names = | occupation = Actress | known_for = | spouse = [[Oskar Homolka]] (1928-1937)
[[Howard Gould]] (1937-1948)
Robert Cooper }} '''Margarete Emma Dorothea''' "'''Grete'''" '''Mosheim''' (8 January 1905 – 29 December 1986) was a German film, theatre, and television actress of Jewish ancestry (on her father's side). ==Early life== Mosheim was born in [[Berlin]], Germany on 8 January 1905, the daughter of Markus Mosheim (1868-1956) and his wife Clara Mosheim née Hilger (1875-1970).{{cite web |title=Mosheim (Grete) papers |website=[[University of Southern California]] Libraries and Archives |url=http://www.usc.edu/libraries/archives/arc/findingaids/mosheim/ |accessdate=30 August 2015 }} Her sister was actress [[:de:Lore Mosheim]], who appeared in at least nine movies. ==Theatre== Mosheim started her acting career at the age of 17 and was a member of [[Deutsches Theater (Berlin)|Deutsches Theater]], Berlin from 1922 to 1931. She began studying at [[Max Reinhardt]]'s School of Drama under [[Berthold Held]] in early 1922, alongside [[Marlene Dietrich]]. Mosheim became established under Max Reinhardt, and in 1925 he gave her the chance to substitute in the play ''Der sprechende Affe''''The Speaking Ape''; original title: ''Le singe qui parle''. by [[René Fauchois]] when the female lead became ill. Mosheim learned the difficult role from [[Albert Bassermann]] in just 24 hours and became a [[superstar]] almost overnight. Until 1933, when she went to London to escape [[Adolf Hitler]]'s rise to power, she was pre-eminent in the Berlin theatre scene. She performed in a wide variety of roles, being equally at home in drama and comedy. She also appeared in musical revues and recorded songs by [[Friedrich Hollaender]]{{cite AV media |title=Grete Mosheim ... Eine kleine Sehnsucht! |medium=song }} [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SiBCz9z_pxg In YouTube]. and others. After intensive study, she mastered English well enough to appear in ''Two Share a Dwelling''{{cite news |date=23 October 1935 |title=New plays and films in London |newspaper=The Straits Times |p=19 }} [http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19351023-1.2.144.aspx In NewspaperSG - NLB]. in London in 1935. She appeared again on stage in Germany from 1952 on, but did not return to films - other than in a few TV roles - until her appearance as the grandmother in ''[[Moritz, Dear Moritz]]'' in 1978. ==Films== Mosheim appeared in numerous German films, mostly silent movies, starting with ''Michael'' in 1924. Until she fled Germany in 1933, she starred in many films, including ''[[Dreyfus (1930 film)|Dreyfus]]'' (1930) and ''[[Yorck]]'' (1931). In 1935 she starred in the British film ''[[Car of Dreams]]''.{{Cite AV media |people=[[Graham Cutts]], [[Austin Melford]] (directors) |year=1935 |title=Car of Dreams |medium=motion picture |website=Internet Archive |url=https://archive.org/details/CarOfDreams1935 |accessdate=30 August 2015 }} ==Personal life== Mosheim was married three times: to actor [[Oskar Homolka]] in Berlin (1928-1933), to industrialist [[Howard Gould]] in London (1937-1948) and to journalist Robert Cooper, who was a correspondent for [[The Times]].{{cite web |author=Andreas Bornemann |title=Grete Mosheim (1905-1986)|website=Postkarten-Archiv |language=de |url=http://www.postkarten-archiv.de/grete-mosheim.html |accessdate=30 August 2015 }}{{cite news |title=Greta Mosheim, 81, A German Leading Lady Of The Theater |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/12/30/obituaries/greta-mosheim-81-a-german-leading-lady-of-the-theater.html |website=New York Times - Obituaries |accessdate=30 August 2015}} She had no children. ==Death== Grete Mosheim died from cancer in New York City on 29 December 1986, aged 81. ==Honours== In 1984, she was awarded the [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]], Germany's highest civilian award. ==Partial filmography== * ''[[Michael (1924 film)|Michael]]'' (Germany 1924) * ''[[Derby (film)|Derby]]'' (Germany 1926) * ''[[The Flames Lie]]'' (Germany 1926) * ''[[The Fiddler of Florence]]'' (Germany 1926) * ''[[Young Blood (film)|Young Blood]]'' (Germany 1926) * ''[[Assassination (1927 film)|Assassination]]'' (Germany 1927) * ''[[The Awakening of Woman]]'' (Germany 1927) * ''[[The Sporck Battalion (1927 film)|The Sporck Battalion]]'' (Germany 1927) * ''[[Carnival Magic (1927 film)|Carnival Magic]]'' (Germany 1927) * ''Die Siebzehnjährigen'' (Germany 1928) * ''[[The Little Slave]]'' (Germany 1928) * ''[[The Green Alley]]'' (Germany 1928) * ''[[Cyanide (1930 film)|Cyanide]]'' (Germany 1930) * ''[[Dreyfus (1930 film)|Dreyfus]]'' (Germany 1930) * ''[[The Murderer Dimitri Karamazov]]'' (Germany 1931) * ''[[Yorck]]'' (Germany 1931) * ''[[Poor as a Church Mouse]]'' (Germany 1931) * ''[[Car of Dreams]]'' (UK 1935) * ''Underground and Emigrants'' (US 1976) * ''[[Moritz, Dear Moritz|Moritz, lieber Moritz]]'' (Germany 1978) ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{DNB portal|104723475|TYP=}} * {{IMDb name|0608653}} * [http://film.virtual-history.com/person.php?personid=669 Photographs of Grete Mosheim in Virtual History]. * [http://www.usc.edu/libraries/archives/arc/findingaids/mosheim/index.html Grete Mosheim on USC archives]. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mosheim, Grete}} [[Category:1905 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:German stage actresses]] [[Category:German film actresses]] {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Ivan Sergeyevich Obolensky | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1925|5|15}} | birth_place = [[London]], [[England]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | education = [[St. George's School, Newport|St. George's School]] | alma_mater = [[Yale University]] | spouse = {{marriage|Claire Elizabeth McGinnis
|1949|1956|reason=div}}
{{marriage|Mary Elizabeth Morris
|1959|2006|reason=her death}} | children = 4 | parents = [[Serge Obolensky|Sergei Platonovich Obolensky]]
[[Ava Alice Muriel Astor]] | relatives = ''See'' [[Astor family]] }} [[Prince]] '''Ivan Sergeyevich Obolensky''' (born 15 May 1925) is an American New York City-based [[financial analyst]] and corporate officer. He was previously commissioned in the [[United States Navy]], serving as a Flight Lieutenant, and has also been a publisher. ==Early life== Obolensky was born in London, [[Middlesex]], on 15 May 1925, to [[Serge Obolensky|Sergei Platonovich "Serge" Obolensky]] and [[Ava Alice Muriel Astor]]. Through his mother, he is a great-great-great-grandson of [[John Jacob Astor]] and the elder grandson of [[John Jacob Astor IV]], who died on the [[RMS Titanic]]. Ivan was educated at [[St. George's School, Newport|St. George's School]] in [[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport]], Rhode Island, and graduated from [[Yale University]] in [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven]], Connecticut, in 1947. While at Yale, he was a member of [[St. Elmo (secret society)|St. Elmo]], a senior [[secret society]]. ==Career== After Yale, Obolensky became a writer working for Telavid Inc. Imports, and went on to serve with the [[United States Navy]] as a pilot. In 1957, he formed a publishing firm McDowell, Obolensky Inc. with a partner, David McDowell. The firm published [[James Agee]]'s [[Pulitzer Prize]] novel, ''[[A Death in the Family]]'' (1957), and was the U.S. publisher for [[Chinua Achebe]]'s ''[[Things Fall Apart]]'' (1959). It was dissolved in 1960. Obolensky then formed a second publishing house, Ivan Obolensky, Inc. This firm continued through 1965, when he joined the investment banking firm of A. T. Brod & Company as a partner.{{cite news |title=The Media Business: Financial Analyst of Publishing Companies Who's Done a Thing or Two |author=[[Edwin McDowell]] |date=9 October 1989 |work=[[New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/09/business/media-business-financial-analyst-publishing-companies-who-s-done-thing-two.html|quote=Even if there were such a thing as a typical Wall Street investment banker, Ivan Obolensky, the senior vice president of research for Josephthal & Company, would not be it. That is, not unless the typical investment banker was also the London-born son of a Russian prince and a grandson of John Jacob Astor, who is said to have been the wealthiest man in America when he went down with the Titanic. Mr. Obolensky, 64 years old, is also a Yale graduate, novelist, former United States Navy pilot and one-time book publisher whose first list produced James Agee's Pulitzer Prize novel, ''A Death in the Family.'' .....}}The publishing house continued until 1968 under the name Astor-Honor. Throughout his main career on [[Wall Street]] as a [[financial analyst]], Obolensky has covered many prestigious accounts. He was Vice President of Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Inc., [[Brokerage firm|Stock brokers]] and is currently Vice President of Shields & Company. Obolensky is an active member of the philanthropic community in New York. He has, for many years, been an active supporter of the [[Soldiers', Sailors', Marines', Coast Guard and Airmen's Club]],{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704380504575530460412010040 |title=A Welcome Mat for Soldiers and Sailors |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=4 October 2010}} and New York's [[International Debutante Ball]],{{cite news |url=http://observer.com/2010/12/the-luckiest-girls-in-the-world-white-tie-endures-at-the-international-debutante-ball/ |title=The Luckiest Girls in the World |work=[[The New York Observer]] |date=30 December 2010}} which benefits the club. He is also Treasurer of the [[Russian Nobility Association in America]], Inc.,{{cite web|title=Officers|url=http://www.russiannobility.org/member.aspx|publisher=Russian Nobility Association Website|accessdate=20 January 2014}} and the US Prior of the [[Russian tradition of the Knights Hospitaller|Orthodox Order of St. John]].{{cite web|last=Cardile|first=Paul|title=Charity, Good Deeds, Culture: The Knights of the Orthodox Order of St. John, Russian Grand Priory|url=http://www.socialregisteronline.com/#!charitygooddeedsculture/c1sw3|publisher=Social Register|accessdate=20 January 2014}} ==Personal life== Obolensky first married in New York City on October 10, 1949 to Claire Elizabeth McGinnis (1929–2015).{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Claire Obolensky Excommunicated After Wedding in Russian Church |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1949/10/14/archives/claire-obolensky-excommunicated-after-wedding-in-russian-church.html |quote=The New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese announced yesterday the excommunication from the church of the former Miss Claire Elizabeth McGinnis, who was married here on Monday to Ivan Obolensky. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=14 October 1949 |accessdate=26 October 2010 }}{{cite news|last1=Staff|title=Claire McGinnis Stephenson|url=https://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/news/local-obituaries/claire-mcginnis-stephenson/xGEafwAN7lIO5MIUL6duKO/|accessdate=23 April 2018|work=[[Palm Beach Daily News]]|date=April 24, 2015|language=en}} Claire was educated at the [[Convent of the Sacred Heart High School (California)|Convent of the Sacred Heart]] in San Francisco, the Finch Junior College in [[Manhattan]], and at [[Katherine Delmar Burke School|Miss Burke's School]] in San Francisco. She was the daughter of Felix Signoret McGinnis (1883–1945), vice-president of the [[Southern Pacific Company]], and Clara ([[née]] Leonhardt) McGinnis (1887–1984). Before their divorce in 1956,http://www.howardmcginnis.com/retrospect/index.php?m=family&id=I34655 Ivan and Claire were the parents of one daughter and two sons: * Princess Marina "Maria" Ivanovna Obolensky (b. 1951), who married N. Carlton. She later married William D. Folwick (1932–2017).{{cite news|title=Obituary for William D. Folwick|url=https://www.startribune.com/obituaries/detail/198207/?fullname=william-d-folwick|accessdate=23 April 2018|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=May 14, 2017}} * Prince Ivan Ivanovich Obolensky (b. 1952), who married Mary Jo Smith without issue. * Prince David Ivanovich Obolensky (b. 1953), who married Mary Catherine Hicks (b. 1952) on March 21, 1981.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/01/style/mary-catherine-hicks-engaged.html | work=[[New York Times]] | title=Mary Catherine Hicks Engaged | date=1 February 1981 |quote=Mary Catherine Hicks and David Ivanovich Obolensky plan to be married March 21. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Thomas Hicks of Nashville, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Garrick C. Stephenson and Ivan Obolensky, both of New York, and a descendant of the original John Jacob Astor..... His father is a vice-president of Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Inc., stockbrokers. The future bridegroom is a grandson of Clara Leonhardt of San Francisco, the late Felix S. McGinnis, who was a vice president of the Southern Pacific Railroad; the late Ava Astor, and the late Serge Obolensky of New York, who ran his own public relations concern.| accessdate=5 May 2010}} After their divorce, Claire married designer and art advisor Garrick C. Stephenson (1927–2007).{{cite news|title=Paid Notice: Deaths STEPHENSON, GARRICK C.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E05E5D9163AF93AA35751C0A9619C8B63|accessdate=23 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 February 2007}}{{cite news|last1=Korb|first1=Priscila|title=Southampton Estate of Late Designer Garrick C. Stephenson Put on the Market|url=https://patch.com/new-york/southampton/southampton-estate-late-designer-garrick-c-stephenson-put-market-0|accessdate=23 April 2018|work=Southampton, NY Patch|date=27 August 2015}} On October 22, 1959, Obolensky married for the second time to Mary Elizabeth Morris (1934–2006).{{cite web|title=Paid Notice: Deaths OBOLENSKY, MARY ELIZABETH MORRIS|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CEEDF173AF937A1575BC0A9609C8B63|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=August 2006}}http://bellevueholidayrentals.com/russianaristocracy/600.html Together, they were the parents of one son: * Prince Sergei Ivanovich Obolensky (b. 1960), unmarried and without issue. ===Descendants=== Through his son David, he is the grandfather of Princess Natalya Elizabeth Davidovna Obolensky (b. 1984) and Princess Octavia Willing Davidovna Obolensky (b. 1989). == See also == * [[Burke's Peerage|''Burke's Peerage & Baronetage'']] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * {{cite web |last=Theroff |first=Paul |url=http://www.angelfire.com/realm/gotha/gotha/obolensky.html |title= Obolensky |publisher=www.angelfire.com/realm/gotha/ (Paul Theroff’s Royal Genealogy Site)}} * [http://wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=cbryant6&id=I098035 www.ancestry.com] * [http://wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=cbryant6&id=I098049 www.ancestry.com] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Obolensky, Ivan Sergeyevich}} [[Category:Rurikids]] [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Obolensky family]] [[Category:Astor family]] [[Category:Schermerhorn family]] [[Category:Livingston family]] [[Category:People from London]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]]

[[File:JapanConsulateHoustonTX.JPG|thumb|Consulate-General of Japan in Houston]] [[File:2HoustonCenterView.JPG|thumb|[[Houston Center#2 Houston Center|2 Houston Center]], the location of the consulate]] The {{nihongo|'''Consulate-General of Japan in Houston'''|在ヒューストン日本国総領事館|''Zai Hyūsuton Nippon-koku Sōryōjikan''}} is [[Japan]]'s diplomatic facility in [[Houston]], [[Texas]], [[United States]]. It is located in Suite 3000 at [[2 Houston Center]], which is located at 900 Fannin Street in [[Downtown Houston]]. The consulate serves Texas and [[Oklahoma]].<ref>"[http://www.us.emb-japan.go.jp/jicc/HoustonLink.htm Consulate-General of Japan in Houston] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080629075939/http://www.us.emb-japan.go.jp/jicc/HoustonLink.htm |date=2008-06-29 }}." [[Embassy of Japan in Washington, D.C.]] Retrieved on December 24, 2008.</ref>
==History== At one point the consulate was located in Suite 5300 and later Suite 2300 in the [[Wells Fargo Plaza (Houston)|Wells Fargo Plaza]] (formerly the First Interstate Bank Plaza).<ref>"[http://www.library.ohiou.edu/subjects/eastasia/diplomat.htm East Asia Diplomatic Representatives in the United States]." ''[[Ohio University]]''. Retrieved on December 24, 2008.</ref><ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20020804090635/http://www.houston.us.emb-japan.go.jp/</ref>
For a decade ending in 1993 the consulate refused to pay "user fees" billed to the consulate by the [[Piney Point Village, Texas|City of Piney Point Village]] in the [[Greater Houston Area]]. The consul general residence is in Piney Point Village. The Japanese argued that this was a tax and that diplomatic facilities should not be taxed.<ref>Tolson, Mike. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20110522080629/http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1993_1154709 Piney Point Village tells Japanese Consulate to pay its way/$14, 000 in user fees, or forget garbage pickup]." ''[[Houston Chronicle]]''. Tuesday September 21, 1993. A11. Retrieved on January 13, 2009.</ref> In 1993 the city announced that the consulate owed the city around $14,000 [[United States dollar]]s.<ref>"[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DM&p_theme=dm&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0ED3D3B4313CF8B8&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM City says Japan owes $14,000 consulate debt]." ''[[Associated Press]]''. September 22, 1993. Retrieved on December 24, 2008.</ref> The Japanese argued that international agreements exempted consulate facilities from taxes, while Piney Point Village said the annual fees were for user services. James Baker, a Piney Point Village alderman, threatened to suspend garbage pickup services and expose the Japanese consulate to ridicule. In September of that year a [[U.S. State Department]] letter stated that consulates should pay legitimate user fees, and that consulates do not have to pay for fire and police services. The consulate paid almost $12,000, including $4,500 in interest, to the city. According to Vice-Consul Takaki Takinami originally the city charged $14,915.52 before changing the invoice and deducting police and fire costs. Shojiro Imanishi (今西 正次郎 ''Imanishi Shōjirō''), who was the outgoing consul-general, agreed to pay $4,500 annually.<ref>Tolson, Mike. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20110522080424/http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1993_1171952 Japanese consul coughs up Piney Point's fees]." ''[[Houston Chronicle]]''. Wednesday December 15, 1993. Section A, Page 36. Retrieved on January 13, 2009.</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:2HoustonCenterSign.JPG|[[Houston Center#2 Houston Center|2 Houston Center]], the location of the consulate File:Wells_Fargo_Bank_Plaza,_Houston,_from_base.jpg|[[Wells Fargo Plaza (Houston)|Wells Fargo Plaza]], the former location of the consulate </gallery>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''Julian Brind''' MW (5 November 1942 – 19 December 2010) was a British [[Master of Wine]] and director of buying wines, beers, spirits and soft drinks for the [[Waitrose]] supermarket chain.<ref name="telegraph">{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/8279682/Julian-Brind.html |title=Julian Brind: Obituaries Supermarket buyer who introduced Britons to the wines of the New World |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=24 January 2011 |accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> Brind was a key figure in the transformation of the British wine trade from the 1970s onwards.<ref name="times">{{cite web |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/opinion/obituaries/article2859653.ece |title=Julian Brind: Influential wine trader who was the first to ship New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc to Britain in 1973 |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date=1 January 2011 |accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref>
==Career== Julian Brind was born in [[Scotland]] and educated at [[Strathallan School]] in Perthshire.<ref name="telegraph" /> After school he followed his father into the wine and spirits trade joining Brown & Pank, part of [[Watney, Combe & Reid|Watney Mann Breweries]] as a management trainee.<ref name="telegraph" /><ref name="decanter">{{cite web |url=http://www.decanter.com/news/wine-news/511078/julian-brind-dies |title=Julian Brind |magazine=[[Decanter (magazine)|Decanter]] |date=21 December 2010 |accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> Brind started buying wine under the direction of Don Lovell MW, who put him forward for the Vintners' Scholarship, which he was awarded in 1967.<ref name="decanter" /> In the same year he also won the Bourse de Voyage scholarship.<ref name="offlicencenews">{{cite web |url=http://www.offlicencenews.co.uk/news/archivestory.php/aid/3406/Wine_trade_mourns_death_of_Julian_Brind_MW.html |title=Wine trade mourns death of Julian Brind MW |newspaper=Off Licence News |date=20 December 2010 |accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> In 1970, Brind passed the Master of Wine exam and joined Waitrose to lead the wine buying team in 1971.<ref name="decanter" /><ref name="drinksbusiness" />
When Brind joined Waitrose in the early seventies the wine consumer in Britain was served by the traditional wine merchant selling [[Old World wine]] from prestigious European growers.<ref name="times" /> Selling wine in supermarkets was in its infancy.<ref name="indie" /> Brind recognised that there was an opportunity to introduce the consumer to new wines from all over the world.<ref name="times" /> In 1973 he was the first buyer to introduce [[New Zealand wine|New Zealand]] [[Sauvignon blanc]] to Britain.<ref name="times" /> Nonetheless, Brind did not neglect the traditional European market; instigating the [[Vin de pays]] revolution from southern [[French wine|France]].<ref name="telegraph" /><ref name="times" /> So began the interest in [[New World wine]] and a cultural shift away from the traditional wine merchant toward the supermarket.<ref name="telegraph" />
At Waitrose, Brind continued the policy of hiring good buyers and letting them get on with it.<ref name="indie">{{cite web |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/312082369/140F831EFF128FC31C9/4?accountid=15842 |title=Living Review: Drink – My Round ; Now raise your glasses and wish a very happy retirement to the man who put the sparkle into supermarket wine: |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=19 May 2002 |accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref> By the early 1990s Brind had hired a team of five wine buyers, all of whom were experts in their own field, and Masters of Wine.<ref name="guardian">{{cite web |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/293492985/140F8AB62FA6A91735A/3?accountid=15842 |title=Drink: Waitrose wines: Supermarket forces Tim Atkin on a retailer riding high with dignity |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=23 October 1994 |accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref> Under his direction, the 'Waitrose list' became known for its emphasis on individual wines from individual producers.<ref name="indie" /> Brind insisted on limiting big brand and own-label wines.<ref name="indie" /> He lamented the dominance of the big brands in the market place through deep discounting and the adverse effect it had on the real wine business.<ref name="indie" /> For this reason Brind emphasised the need for wine specialists in each store.<ref name="indie" /> Thus Waitrose developed a reputation for providing interesting wines, not sold by any other supermarket.<ref name="indie" /><ref name="guardian2">{{cite web |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/293447550/140FDD272B96AAEA501/18?accountid=15842 |title=SUPERPLONK SPECIAL:Taking Pride in Prejudices |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 November 1992 |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> Under Brind's stewardship both Waitrose and Brind won numerous domestic and international awards.<ref name="guardian" /><ref name="grocer">{{cite web |url=http://www.thegrocer.co.uk/fmcg/brind-honoured-in-waitrose-drinks-praise/83277.article |title=Brind Honoured in Waitrose drinks praise |magazine=[[The Grocer]] |date=8 February 2003 |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="newswire">{{cite web |url=http://www.prnewswire.co.uk/news-releases/waitrose-wins-supermarket-wine-merchant-of-the-year-award-156101055.html |title=Waitrose wins supermarket Wine Merchant of the Year award |publisher=[[PR Newswire]] |year=2000 |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref>
Brind held numerous positions within the wine trade: chair of the Masters of Wine Panel of Examiners;<ref name="drinksbusiness">{{cite web |url=http://www.thedrinksbusiness.com/2010/12/julian-brind-mw-dies/ |title=Julian Brind MW dies |magazine=The Drinks Business |date=20 December 2010 |accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> chairman of the Institute of Masters of Wine, 1993;<ref name="robinson">{{cite web |url=http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/a2010122011.html |title=Julian Brind MW |publisher=[[Jancis Robinson]] |date=20 December 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> ombudsman to the Circle of Wine Writers, 2001;<ref name="drinksbusiness" /> president of the [[Wine and Spirit Trade Association]], 2002<ref name="robinson" /> and chairman of the Trustees of the [[Wine & Spirit Education Trust]], 2003.<ref name="WSET" />
Since Brind's death several awards and scholarships have been established to commemorate his career in the wine trade.<ref name="WSET" /><ref name="drinksbusiness2" /> In 2011 The Wine and Spirit Education Trust established The Julian Brind Memorial Scholarship.<ref name="WSET">{{cite web |url=http://www.wsetglobal.com/qualifications/scholarships/uk_scholarships/58.asp |title=WSET Awards of Excellence – Advanced 2011 Winners |publisher=[[Wine & Spirit Education Trust]] |year=2011 |accessdate=8 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020092341/http://wsetglobal.com/qualifications/scholarships/uk_scholarships/58.asp |archivedate=20 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In the same year the [[International Wine and Spirit Competition]] established the Julian Brind Memorial Award for Outstanding Achievement in the Wine Industry.<ref name="drinksbusiness2">{{cite web |url=http://www.thedrinksbusiness.com/2013/08/iwsc-unveils-outstanding-achievement-shortlist |title=IWSC unveils Outstanding Achievement shortlist |magazine=[[The Drinks Business (magazine)|The Drinks Business]] |date=14 August 2013 |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> The inaugural trophy was awarded to 'Julian Brind'.<ref name="IWSC2">{{cite web |url=http://www.iwsc.net/2011-peopletrophies |title=IWSC 2011 People Trophies |publisher=[[International Wine and Spirit Competition]] |year=2011 |accessdate=9 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014234634/http://www.iwsc.net/2011-peopletrophies |archivedate=14 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

Milan|Milan]] at a [[Russian Railways Cup]] press conference in 2007 | order = [[Mayor of Tbilisi]] | term_start = 13 November 2017 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Davit Narmania]] | successor = | order2 = Deputy | office2 = Prime Minister of Georgia | term_start2 = 25 October 2012 | term_end2 = 12 July 2017 | predecessor2 = [[Vakhtang Balavadze (politician)|Vakhtang Balavadze]] | successor2 = [[Mikheil Janelidze]] | viceprimeminister2 = [[Irakli Alasania]]
