revision.text:
[[Image:US TIFA2010.png|thumb|right|400px|United States TIFAs {{legend|#000000|'''United States'''}} {{legend|#007f00|'''Bilateral US-partner agreement'''}} {{legend|#00ff00|'''US-trade bloc agreement ([[COMESA]], [[East African Community|EAC]], [[CARICOM]], [[ASEAN]])'''}}]]
A '''Trade and Investment Framework Agreement''' ('''TIFA''') is a [[trade pact]] that establishes a framework for expanding trade and resolving outstanding disputes between [[country|countries]].
TIFAs are often seen as an important step towards establishing [[Free Trade Agreement]]s.
== ASEAN == The [[United States]] and [[ASEAN]] concluded the U.S.-ASEAN Trade and Investment Arrangement (TIFA) in 2006 and since then have been working to build U.S.-ASEAN trade and investment ties as well as promote ASEAN regional economic integration. The United States intensified its work under the TIFA in 2009, presenting ASEAN senior officials a number of ambitious proposals to be pursued under the TIFA work plan. These proposed initiatives seek to achieve concrete results in a variety of areas including trade facilitation, logistics, [[digital economy]], trade finance, and trade and environment. The 10-member countries of ASEAN together comprise the fourth largest export market of the United States and its fifth largest two-way trading partner. ASEAN countries include Brunei, Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam. Trade between the U.S. and ASEAN continues to grow steadily, and two-way goods trade totaled $177 billion in 2008. With robust economies and a total population of about 550 million, the 10-member countries of the ASEAN market provide significant potential [[market opportunity|opportunities]] for U.S. companies.
== Taiwan == The U.S. goods [[trade deficit]] with [[Taiwan]] was $15.2 billion in 2006, an increase of $2.4 billion from $12.8 billion in 2005. U.S. goods exports in 2006 were $23.0 billion, up 4.3 percent from the previous year. Corresponding [[U.S. imports]] from Taiwan were $38.2 billion, up 9.7 percent. Taiwan is as of June 2015, the 11th largest export market for U.S. goods. U.S. exports of private commercial services (excluding military and government) to Taiwan were $6.4 billion in 2005 (latest data available), and U.S. imports were $6.4 billion. Sales of services in Taiwan by majority U.S.-owned affiliates were $10.2 billion in 2004 (latest data available), while sales of services in the United States by majority Taiwan-owned firms were $475 million. The stock of U.S. foreign direct investment (FDI) in Taiwan was $13.4 billion in 2005. U.S. FDI in Taiwan is concentrated largely in the finance, manufacturing and wholesale trade sectors. The United States and Taiwan continued to work together to enhance economic cooperation through bilateral Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) process. The TIFA, which was established in 1994, is an important mechanism for both parties to resolve bilateral trade issues and to address the concerns of the U.S. business community. The United States and Taiwan held a productive meeting of the fifth meeting of the TIFA Joint Council in Taipei, May 25–26, 2006, covering issues related to agricultural trade, intellectual property rights, pharmaceuticals, government procurement and investment, as well as other areas.
== Uruguay == The U.S.-Uruguay commercial relationship has developed significantly in the past several years. In 2002, [[Uruguay]] and the United States created a [[Joint Commission on Trade and Investment]] (JCTI) to exchange ideas on a variety of economic topics. The Commission served as an important mechanism for the two countries to work to enhance and broaden their trade relationship, and facilitated the successful negotiation of the United States - Uruguay Bilateral Investment Treaty (BIT), which entered into force on November 1, 2006. The United States and Uruguay signed the United States - Uruguay TIFA on January 25, 2007. The TIFA established the United States - Uruguay Trade and Investment Council (TIC) and serves as a mechanism to further deepen the trade and investment dialogue. On October 2, 2008, both governments signed protocols to the TIFA covering substantive commitments in the areas of trade facilitation and public participation in trade and environment. The TIFA contains an annex that established a work program calling for the two governments to address such matters as [[economic liberalization|liberalization]] of bilateral trade and investment, intellectual property rights, regulatory issues, information and communications technology and electronic commerce, trade facilitation, trade and technical capacity building, trade in services, government procurement, and cooperation on sanitary and phytosanitary measures. The annex provides for the TIC to add other matters to the work program. In implementing the TIFA, both parties reconfirmed their commitment to expand economic opportunities between Uruguay and the United States while simultaneously coordinating their efforts to promote greater [[trade liberalization]] through the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO).
== See also == * [[Bilateral Investment Treaty]] (BIT)
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051120012736/http://ustr.gov/index.html Office of the United States Trade Representative] *[http://www.ustr.gov/sites/default/files/uploads/reports/2008/NTE/asset_upload_file508_14610.pdf TIFA Agreement/Fact with the Republic of China (Taiwan)] *[http://www.ustr.gov/countries-regions/southeast-asia-pacific/association-southeast-asian-nations-asean US and the ASEAN] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090703151317/http://www.ustr.gov/about-us/press-office/press-releases/2009/june/us-uruguay-hold-trade-and-investment-council-meeting Press, U.S., Uruguay Hold Trade and Investment Council Meeting]
[[Category:International trade law]] [[Category:Foreign direct investment]]

{{Infobox company |name = Verified Audit Circulation |logo = |type = Private company |foundation = Los Angeles (1951) |founder = Geraldine Knight |location_city = [[Larkspur, California]] |subsid = |area_served = United States |key_people = Tim Prouty (CEO) |industry = Publishing |products = Circulation audit reports
delivery verification reports
research |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |assets = |equity = |num_employees = |homepage = [http://www.verifiedaudit.com Verifiedaudit.com] }} '''Verified Audit Circulation''' is a United States company founded by Geraldine Knight in 1951 that conducts circulation [[audit]]s of both free and paid print [[publications]] and of traffic figures for web sites. The company also provides custom research and verifies field delivery of products such as [[yellow pages]], branded delivery bags, and [[door]] hangers.{{Cite web | title = Resource Focus: Verified Audit Circulation | work = Article | publisher = MagazineLaunch | date = 13 June 2005 | url = http://www.magazinelaunch.com/how-to/resource-focus/resource-focus-verified-audit-circulation | accessdate = 2 August 2011}} As an independent audit firm, Verified Audit Circulation works with publication circulation figures provided by their publisher clients, to verify or adjust these circulation numbers, based on examining a publication’s printing and financial records. Field research also may be conducted to confirm circulation figures. Circulation audit findings are compiled and released in audit reports, which advertisers use to make decisions about advertising placements.{{Cite web | last = Armor | first = Jennifer | title = How to Purchase Print Advertising Wisely | publisher = National Mail Order Association | url = http://www.nmoa.org/articles/dmnews/Howtopurchaseprintadvertising707.htm | accessdate = 4 August 2011}} ==History== During the mid-twentieth century, traditional paid-circulation newspapers and magazines were joined by a new publication category: free-circulation newspapers and magazines, known as trade or controlled-circulation publications. As free newspapers and magazines increased in number, in 1951, Geraldine Knight founded Verified Audit Circulation as the first company dedicated to auditing these publications.{{Cite web | title = Company History | publisher = Verified Audit Circulation| url = http://www.verifiedaudit.com/history.htm | accessdate = 3 August 2011}} Subsequently, Verified expanded its services to include audits of paid publications, free rack-distributed publications, and products delivered to the door.{{Cite web | title = Company History | publisher = Verified Audit Circulation| url = http://www.verifiedaudit.com/history.htm | accessdate = 29 July 2011}} The addition of web site audits provided site publishers with independent confirmation of site visitor activity and with assurance of web site ad delivery.{{Cite web | title = Resource Focus: Verified Audit Circulation | work = Article | publisher = MagazineLaunch.com | date = 13 June 2005 | url = http://www.magazinelaunch.com/how-to/resource-focus/resource-focus-verified-audit-circulation | accessdate = 3 August 2011}} By 2008, the company was auditing more than 1,000 free and 250 paid publications, along with more than 100 weekly [[alternative newspaper]]s.{{Cite web | last = Hanzlik | first = Mark | title = Print Circulation Audit Firms Continue to Survive in the 21st Century | work = Article | publisher = themacwizard.com| date = February 2008 | url = http://www.themacwizard.com/print-circulation-audit-firms-continue-to-survive-in-the-21st-century/ | accessdate = 5 August 2011}} Its audit clients include ''The Washington Post'', ''The Chicago Tribune'',{{Cite journal | title = Circulation and City and Regional Magazine Association |work = Brochure |publisher = GulfShore Media, LLC | accessdate = 1 September 2011}} and Questex Media.{{Cite web | title = Verified Completes First Integrated Media Audits on Questex Brands | work = Article | publisher = Audience Development.com| date = 10 February 2010 | url = http://www.audiencedevelopment.com/2010/verified+completes+first+integrated+media+audits+questex+brands | accessdate = 1 September 2011}} In 2009, Verified developed and launched an expanded form of integrated audit report to track a larger range of circulation and audience parameters for clients. The new report type addresses the growing diversification of media, beyond print and into electronic formats. The cross-platform audit report supplements print-circulation figures with data on digital editions, events, web sites, webinars, e-newsletters, and supplements.{{Cite web | title = Questex Adopts New Total Audience Audit Process | work = Article | publisher = FOLIO | date = 14 April 2009 | url = http://www.foliomag.com/2009/questex-media-adopts-new-total-audience-audit-process| accessdate = 29 July 2011}}{{Cite web | title = Verified Completes First Integrated Media Audits on Questex Brands | work = Article | publisher = Audience Development.com| date = 10 February 2010 | url = http://www.audiencedevelopment.com/2010/verified+completes+first+integrated+media+audits+questex+brands | accessdate = 30 July 2011}} During 2011, Verified expanded its circulation guidelines to allow publishers to include publications distributed at trade shows and events among their qualified circulation figures. Prior to the update, trade show and event distribution of publications counted as unqualified circulation.{{Cite web | last = Mendolera | first = Katrina |title = Magazines & newspapers can now audit trade show circulation | work = Article | publisher = Vocus.com| date = 14 June 2011 | url = http://www.vocus.com/invocus/media-blog/magazines-newspapers-can-now-audit-trade-show-circulation/ | accessdate = 1 September 2011}} ==Membership== Verified clients are known as members of the organization, and they have full access to the circulation-reporting and member resources on the Verified Audit Circulation web site. Media buyers, advertisers, and [[advertising agencies]] are eligible for free associate membership, which provides online access to audit reports, publisher statements, circulation data downloads, and a Verified e-newsletter.{{Cite web | title = Verified Associate Member Qualification Form | publisher = Verified Audit Circulation | url = http://www.verifiedaudit.com/assocmbrqual.htm | accessdate = 29 July 2011}} Verified Audit Circulation is headquartered in [[Larkspur, California]].{{Cite web | last = Hanzlik| first = Mark | title = Print Circulation Audit Firms Continue to Survive in the 21st Century | work = Article | publisher = themacwizard.com| date = 1 February 2008 | url = http://www.themacwizard.com/print-circulation-audit-firms-continue-to-survive-in-the-21st-century/ | accessdate = 5 August 2011}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Verified Audit Circulation}} [[Category:Newspapers circulation audit]] [[Category:Accounting firms of the United States]] [[Category:Organizations based in California]]

{{Infobox person |name = Viviane Senna |image = Senna viviane.jpg |caption = Viviane Senna in 2006. |birth_name = Viviane Senna da Silva |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|06|14|df=y}} |birth_place = [[São Paulo]], [[Brazil]] |nationality = Brazilian |education = [[Pontifical Catholic University of São Paulo]] |employer = Founder and president of the [[Instituto Ayrton Senna]] and the Ayrton Senna Foundation |occupation = Entrepreneurship
Philanthropy |networth = |spouse = Flávio Lalli (m. ?-1996; his death) |children = [[Bruno Senna]] }} '''Viviane Senna da Silva Lalli''' ({{nee|'''Senna da Silva'''}}; born 14 June 1958) is a Brazilian entrepreneur and philanthropist. She is sister of the racing driver and three-times Formula 1 world champion [[Ayrton Senna]] (1960–1994), and mother of the driver [[Bruno Senna]] (*1983).[http://epoca.globo.com/edic/19990503/soci3.htm «A guardiã do mito: Colada à imagem do irmão, Viviane Senna chega à pole position da filantropia nacional»] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505231638/http://epoca.globo.com/edic/19990503/soci3.htm |date=2009-05-05 }}, ''O Globo'', 3 May 1999. She is president of the Ayrton Senna Foundation, established in London in June 1994 and also of the [[Instituto Ayrton Senna]] organization, headquartered in São Paulo since November 1994. == Biography == Viviane Senna was born in São Paulo to Milton Teodoro Guirado da Silva and Neide Senna da Silva. In 1979 she graduated in Psychology at the [[Pontifícia Universidade Católica de São Paulo|Pontificial Catholic University of São Paulo]], specializing in [[Jungian]] [[Analytical psychology|psychology]] in the university's Sede Sapientiaes Institute. She worked as a psychotherapist for adult and children, and also supervised qualification groups and improvement of psychotherapists.[http://idis.org.br/acontece/noticias/perfil-viviane-senna-lidera-movimento-pela-qualidade-da-educacao-no-pais/ «Perfil: Viviane Senna lidera movimento pela qualidade da educação no Brasil»], artículo en el sitio web IDIS (Instituto para el Desarrollo de la Inversión Social) del 5 de agosto de 2011. She also coordinated study groups of [[Depth psychology|deep psychology]] (advocated by Jung). She received the Grand Prix 2012 [[BNP Paribas]], that recognises worldwide leaders in the area of social investment,[http://www.bnpparibas.com/en/news/press-release/institute-ayrton-senna-and-greenhouse-charity-honoured-bnp-paribas-prize-individu «The Institute Ayrton Senna and the Greenhouse Charity honoured by the BNP Paribas Prize for Individual Philanthropy»], artículo en inglés en el sitio web BNP Paribas del 21 de junio de 2012.] and was appointed one of the Leaders for the New Millennium of CNN/[[Time (magazine)|''Time'']].[http://senna.globo.com/institutoayrtonsenna/quem_somos/presidente.asp «Presidente Viviane Senna»], ficha en el sitio web Senna Globo. She is the only Brazilian member of the Fellow Adults of Boys of the World Prize together with [[Nelson Mandela]] (ex-president of [[South Africa]]), [[Queen Silvia of Sweden|Silvia Renate Sommerlath]] (wife of the king of Sweden), and [[José Ramos-Horta]] (Nobel Prize winner), among others. == Businesswoman == Viviane Senna manages the royalties of the Ayrton Senna brand that through its character [[Senninha]] (based on the driver) has been reproduced in more than 200 products, from bicycles to french fries. == Filmography == Viviane Senna has been in three documentaries and two TV series. {| class="wikitable sortable" !Year !Title !Role !Notes |- |1998 |''A Star Named Ayrton Senna'' | rowspan="5" |Herself | rowspan="3" |Documentary |- |2004 |''The Right To Win'' |- | rowspan="2" |2010 |[[Senna (film)|''Senna'']] |- |''Show Business'' |TV series |- |2012 |''Na Moral'' |TV series; episode 1.9 |} == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Senna, Viviane}} [[Category:Brazilian activists]] [[Category:Pontifical Catholic University of São Paulo alumni]] [[Category:Brazilian businesspeople]] [[Category:20th-century women]] [[Category:21st-century women]] [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:People from São Paulo (state)]] [[Category:Brazilian psychologists]] [[Category:Living people]] {{Brazil-business-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox Organization |name = Wharton India Economic Forum |image = WIEF.png |size = 225px |abbreviation = WIEF |formation = 1996 |type = Business Conference |location = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], United States |purpose = To raise the profile of the economic potential of India |leader_title = Chairpersons |leader_name = Juhi Bhatnagar, Kartik Das, Khushboo Goel, Sonal Panda, Swati Ganeti |website = {{URL|WhartonIndia.com}} }} The '''Wharton India Economic Forum''' (WIEF), established in 1996 at The [[Wharton School]], is a student-run business forum in the United States focused on India.<ref>{{cite web|title=India’s Ahluwalia Says "More Room" for Interest Rate Cuts|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&refer=India&sid=aiUS1fP1XdgU|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref> WIEF is one of the largest India-based economic and business conferences in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chiefs spruik India's home turf|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/chiefs-spruik-indias-home-turf/story-e6frg8zx-1111112563509|publisher=The Australian}}</ref> It is attended by over 800 people annually and receives extensive media coverage in India and the wider business by leading publications, such as [[The Wall Street Journal]], [[Forbes]], [[The New York Times]], [[The Economic Times]] and [[The Times of India]].
WIEF's describes its mission as to "engage the world's attention on India's enormous potential and the limitless possibilities the country offers".
== Speakers at the pre-2012 conferences ==
'''Government & Policy''' *Dr. [[A.P.J Abdul Kalam]], 11th President of India *[[P. Chidambaram]], Home Affairs Minister and former Finance Minister of India *[[Henry Paulson]], 74th United States Treasury Secretary and former CEO and Chairman of Goldman Sachs *Dr. [[Montek Singh Ahluwalia]], Deputy Chairman, Planning Commission, Government of India *[[Shashi Tharoor]], Member of Indian Parliament and former Under Secretary General of the United Nations *[[Praful Patel]], Minister of State for Civil Aviation, Government of India *[[Sachin Pilot]], Minister of State, Ministry of Communications & Information Technology, Government of India *[[Naveen Jindal]], Member of Indian Parliament *Kalpana Kochhar, Country Head India, International Monetary Fund
'''Industry''' *[[Anil Ambani]], Chairman, Reliance Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group *[[Mukesh Ambani]], Chairman and MD, Reliance Industries *[[Sunil Mittal]], Founder, Chairman and Group CEO, Bharti Enterprises *[[N. R. == 16th WIEF, 2012==
The 16th annual Wharton India Economic Forum was held on January 9, 2012 in Mumbai, India. This was the first time the WIEF was held in India.
The speakers included:
*[[K.V. Kamath]], Chairman, Infosys Limited *[[Ajay Piramal]], Chairman, Piramal Enterprises Limited *[[Chanda Kochhar]], MD & CEO, ICICI Bank *Keki Mistry, Vice Chairman and CEO, HDFC Limited *Niranjan Hiranandani, Co-Founder and MD, Hiranandani Group *[[R Gopalakrishnan]], Director, Tata Sons *Vinod Rai, Comptroller & Auditor General of India *Gunit Chadha, MD & CEO, Deutsche Bank India *Manish Kejriwal, ex-India Head, Temasek Holdings
== 17th WIEF, 2013 ==
'''Keynote Speakers'''
* [[Montek Singh Ahluwalia]] (via live videoconference) - Deputy Chairman, Planning Commission of India * [[Arvind Kejriwal]], Founder, Aam Aadmi Party * [[Ron Somers]] - President, US-India Business Council * [[Dilip Cherian]] - Consulting Partner, Perfect Relations (Moderator)
[[Milind Deora]] opted out for an unspecified reason.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_arvind-kejriwal-mohandas-pai-to-speak-at-wharton-deora-drops-out_1810617 | title = Arvind Kejriwal, Mohandas Pai to speak at Wharton; Deora drops out | newspaper = DNA | date = 2013-03-13 | accessdate = 2013-03-13 }}</ref>
'''Media and Entertainment Panelists'''
* [[Javed Akhtar]] - Poet, Lyricist, and Scriptwriter * [[Shabana Azmi]] - Actress * [[Boman Irani]] - Actor * [[Aseem Chhabra]] - Freelance writer (Moderator) * [[Sudhir Mishra]] - Director and Screenwriter
'''Women's Empowerment Panelists'''
* [[Lakshmi Pratury]] - Co-Host, TEDIndia * [[Shabana Azmi]] - Actress * [[Vrinda Grover]] - Lawyer, High Court India * [[Jaideep Bose]] - Editorial Director, Times of India Group (Moderator)
'''Private Equity/Venture Capital Panelists'''
* [[Shankar Narayanan]] - MD, The Carlyle Group India
'''Finance Panelists'''
* L.N. Balaji - President, ITC Infotech USA * [[Thomas Brunner]] - Partner & General Counsel, [[LeapFrog Investments]] * Amit Saxena - CEO, [[Karvy]] Financial Services Limited
'''Entrepreneurship Panelists'''
* Sasha Mirchandani -Managing Director and Founder, Kae Capital * Samir Mitra - Advisor, [[Prime Minister of India]] * Aneesh Reddy - Co-Founder and CEO, [[Capillary Technologies]] * [[Devita Saraf]] - Chief Executive Officer, Vu Technologies
=== Narendra Modi Controversy ===
In 2013, the WIEF organizers invited the Gujarat chief minister [[Narendra Modi]] to deliver the keynote address via video-conferencing.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://zeenews.india.com/news/nation/wharton-snub-support-grows-for-narendra-modi_832838.html | title = Wharton snub: Support grows for Narendra Modi | date = 2013-03-04 | accessdate = 2013-03-04 | publisher = Zee News }}</ref> Toorjo Ghose, an assistant professor at the University of Pennsylvania and a small group of colleagues put together a petition after learning about Wharton's invitation to Modi. Kasturi Sen, a Philadelphia-based attorney, created a group on Facebook and initially hosted the petition there.<ref>[http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-03-05/news/37469804_1_responsible-student-body-organisers-wharton-india-economic-forum Narendra Modi's address at Wharton nulled via Facebook, ET Bureau, Economic Times, Mar 5, 2013]</ref> The petition cited the [[India–United States relations#2005 Denial of Visa Application and Revocation of Visa|revocation of visa to Modi]] in 2005 by the US state department.<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303380004579520041301275638 Why Narendra Modi Was Banned From the U.S., JAMES MANN Wall Street Journal, May 2, 2014]</ref> They were joined by Ania Loomba and Suvir Kaul, both Indian-American [[University of Pennsylvania|UPenn]] professors, who were critical of Modi's handling of the [[2002 Gujarat violence|2002 Hindu-Muslim riots]], started formal a petition demanding the cancellation of the invitation, failing which they would protest his virtual presence at the event.<ref>[http://www.thedp.com/article/2013/03/petition-against-narendra-modis-invitation-to-the-wharton-india-economic-forum Petition against Narendra Modi's invitation to the Wharton India Economic Forum, By PETITIONERS, The Daily Pennsylvanian, 03/10/13]</ref>
The petition was sent to [[Amy Gutmann]], the UPenn president. The university leadership stepped in to diffuse what it saw as a potentially explosive situation.<ref>[http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/newdelhi/inside-story-why-wharton-cancelled-modi-s-lecture/article1-1021161.aspx Inside story: why Wharton cancelled Modi's lecture, Charu Sudan Kasturi, Hindustan Times New Delhi, March 05, 2013]</ref> The WIEF organizers had to cancel the invitation, even though they stood by the earlier decision to invite Modi. They stated that they wanted to avoid putting Modi in a "compromising position".<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-21651603 | title = India minister Narendra Modi's US speech cancelled | publisher = BBC | date = 2013-03-03 | accessdate = 2013-03-07 }}</ref> At the time of the decision, the petition had been signed by around 135 people, and the number of signatories grew to 250 later.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_a-petition-signed-by-about-135-people-behind-wharton-s-decision-to-cancel-narendra-modi-invite_1807248 | title = A petition signed by about 135 people behind Wharton's decision to cancel Narendra Modi invite | newspaper = DNA | date = 2013-03-04 | accessdate = 2013-03-07 }}</ref> A senior Wharton official distanced Wharton from the decision stating “Make no mistake, the move to not have Modi was a result of UPenn, not Wharton,” pointing to the fact that not a single Wharton faculty member had signed the petition demanding cancellation of Modi's speech.
In Modi's support, the [[Shiv Sena]] leader [[Suresh Prabhakar Prabhu]] scrapped his visit to Wharton.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.deccanherald.com/content/316390/sena-leader-prabhu-cancels-wharton.html | title = Sena leader Prabhu cancels Wharton visit after Modi snub |work= India Today |date= 2013-03-04 |accessdate= 2013-03-04 |publisher= Zee News }}</ref> Another speaker, the Wall Street Journal writer and journalist [[Sadanand Dhume]], also pulled out from the forum in protest.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/columnist-sadanand-dhume-opts-out-of-wharton-forum-113030500661_1.html | title = Columnist Sadanand Dhume opts out of Wharton forum | newspaper = Business Standard | date = 2013-03-05 | accessdate = 2013-03-08 }}</ref> He was replaced by [[Padma Shri Awards (2010–2019)#2010|Sudhir Parikh]], a New Jersey-based eminent physician, philanthropist, publisher and [[Padma Shri]] awardee. However, Parikh too withdrew from the conference as a mark of protest. He stated, ''"The manner in which the committee has been pressurised to rescind its invitation to Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi on entirely suspicious grounds, I feel the intellectual integrity of the forum has been compromised."''<ref name="Indian-American pulls out of WIEF">{{cite news|title=Indian-American pulls out of WIEF|url=http://www.dailypioneer.com/india-abroad/indian-american-pulls-out-of-wharton-india-economic-forum.html|accessdate=26 March 2013|newspaper=The Pioneer|date=14 March 2013}}</ref> [[Ron Somers]], also a keynote speaker, termed the decision to drop Modi as "unfortunate and disrespectful", but said that he would attend the event in order to make his point about free speech.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/NorthAmerica/Wharton-Modi-controversy-unfortunate-and-disrespectful-USIBC/Article1-1022062.aspx | title = Wharton-Modi controversy unfortunate and disrespectful: USIBC | newspaper = Hindustan Times | date = 2013-03-04 | accessdate = 2013-03-07 }}</ref> Another keynote speaker [[Mohandas Pai]] also backed out complaining about mistreatment of Indians outside India; he mentioned the "shabby" treatment of Narendra Modi among other incidents such as the [[2012 Italian shooting in the Arabian Sea|Italian marines controversy]], Pakistan's reaction to [[Afzal Guru]]'s hanging and Sri Lanka's treatment of Indian fishermen.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-03-15/india/37743320_1_mohandas-pai-indian-fishermen-wharton-event | title = Mohandas Pai says no to Wharton | date = 2013-03-15 | accessdate = 2013-03-15 | newspaper = The Times of India | author = Mini Joseph Tejaswi }}</ref> The U.S. Congressman [[Eni Faleomavaega]] expressed disappointment at the decision, criticizing the protesters as "a segment of professors and students who are reaching beyond the law and coming awfully close to violating the rights of others who have a different view".<ref>[http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/disappointing-that-wharton-rescinded-its-invite-to-narendra-modi-us-lawmaker-338816 'Disappointing that Wharton rescinded its invite to Narendra Modi': US lawmaker]. March 6, 2013</ref> Several others, including [[Rajiv Malhotra]] and the Indian Union Minister [[Shashi Tharoor]] also stated that Modi should not have been disinvited.<ref>[http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/wharton-should-have-heard-narendra-modi-shashi-tharoor-338807 Wharton should have heard Narendra Modi: Shashi Tharoor]</ref><ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rajiv-malhotra/the-hijacking-of-wharton_b_2814421.html The Hijacking of Wharton]</ref>
The [[Adani Group|Adani group]], the platinum sponsors of the event, withdrew their sponsorship.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=791450 | title = Adani Group Withdraws Wharton Event Sponsorship | publisher = Outlook | date = 2013-03-04 | accessdate = 2013-03-07 }}</ref> Subsequently, [[Viacom 18]]'s [[Colors (TV channel)|Colors]], the silver sponsors, also pulled out.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://ibnlive.in.com/news/after-adani-group-viacom18s-colors-pulls-out-of-wharton-forum-as-a-sponsor/377308-3.html | title = After Adani Group, Viacom18's Colors pulls out of Wharton forum as a sponsor | publisher = IBNLive | date = 2013-03-04 | accessdate = 2013-03-07 }}</ref> [[Hexaware]], the bronze sponsor, also withdrew sponsorship, saying that its chairman Atul Nishar (a keynote speaker) would be unable to attend the event due to other business engagements.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/info-tech/hexaware-tech-withdraws-sponsorship-for-wharton-event/article4482231.ece | title = Hexaware Tech withdraws sponsorship for Wharton event | newspaper = The Hindu Business Line | date = 2013-03-06 | accessdate = 2013-03-07 }}</ref>
Some media outlets reported that [[Arvind Kejriwal]] had been invited instead of Modi, but Kejriwal clarified that he had received the invitation several days before the decision to drop Modi was made.<ref>{{ cite news | url = http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/arvind-kejriwal-not-a-replacement-for-narendra-modi-at-wharton-sources-338259 | title = Arvind Kejriwal not a replacement for Narendra Modi at Wharton: Sources | publisher = NDTV | date = 2013-03-05 | accessdate = 2013-03-05}}</ref> Kejriwal also expressed his disapproval of the decision to drop Modi.<ref>[http://ibnlive.in.com/news/wharton-forums-decision-to-disinvite-modi-was-wrong-kejriwal/380788-37-64.html Wharton forum's decision to disinvite Narendra Modi was wrong: Arvind Kejriwal ]</ref>
After the controversy, the organizers announced that no media organizations other than [[TV Asia]] would be allowed to cover the event. This was for the first time in the 17 years history of the event that media was not given free access to cover the forum.<ref>[http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130322/news-current-affairs/article/organisers-bar-media-covering-wharton-india-meet Organisers bar media from covering Wharton India meet]</ref> A coalition of activists opposed to the decision came together under the banner of ''Americans for Free Speech'', and organized a peaceful protest at the venue.<ref>[http://www.thedp.com/article/2013/03/protest-against-removal-of-modi-as-wharton-india-economic-forum-speaker-approved Free speech group to protest Wharton India Economic Forum decision]</ref>
The cancellation of Modi's speech ignited a debate on free speech on UPenn campus.<ref>[http://www.thedp.com/article/2013/04/debate-over-modi-and-free-speech-at-penn-continues Debate over Modi and free speech at Penn continues, By ERICH KESSEL, 04/17/13]</ref> Assem Shukla, Associate Professor of Surgery at the Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania stated: "Penn’s tradition of free speech was celebrated when extreme anti-Israel speakers, Louis Farrakhan of the Nation of Islam and radical Occupy Wall Street protesters held sway on campus. But free speech became an empty homily when it came to the speaker selection of a group of Indian-American business school students"<ref>[http://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/12/why-wharton-made-a-mistake-in-rescinding-narendra-modis-invite/?_r=0 A Conversation With: Prof. Aseem R. Shukla, University of Pennsylvania, NIHARIKA MANDHANA, MARCH 12, 2013]</ref> Loomba stated that disinviting a speaker is also freedom of speech. She said "Modi suporters can beam him in, but not in my house".<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MdL-tZz9uko&feature=youtu.be Debating the Right: Narendra Modi and Penn, A panel hosted by The Penn Government and Politics Association, Apr 20, 2013]</ref>
== WIEF Chairs == * 2019: Juhi Bhatnagar . Kartik Das . Khushboo Goel . Sonal Panda . Swati Ganeti * 2018: Ankit Agarwal · Hena Mehta · Abhinav Prateek · Twishmay Shankar * 2017 : Aman Jain · Ankita Bajaj · Divya Menon · Praveen Chunduru * 2016 : Varun Udeshi · Vibhav Chokhani · Vidur Mahajan · Vikram Arumilli * 2015 : Anna Ahmed · Kirti Choudhary · Alvira Rao · Ankit Saxena * 2014 : Nikhil Khosla · Aditi Ravichandar · Shweta Singh · [[Manoj Vasudevan]] * 2013 : Akshay Bhushan · Salil Gupta · Tanmay Mishra · Tegh Singh Bedi * 2012 : Shuchi Pandya · Parth Shah · Shamik Shah · Tahem Veer Verma * 2011 : Tushar Aggarwal · Rohit Chauhan · Aditya Dada · Saksham Karwal · Derek Kightlinger * 2010 : Rahul Jetley · Vikramjit Singh · Sathyanarayan Anand · Nina Chandra · Jay Raghavan * 2009 : Arjun Ghose · Arjun Madan · Anshul Mittal * 2008 : Vivek Garg · Abhishek Gupta · Vivek Garg · Akshay Madhavan * 2006 : Raj Pandey · Ashish Khemka · Piyush Jain · Sameera Chilakapati * 2005 : Hari Prakash · Amit Soni · Abhishek Chauhan · Kanush Chaudhary * 2004 : Vijay Shreedhar · Samarth Singh · Kunal Bahl * 2003 : Nikhil Sawhney · Niraj Shah · Aditya Talwar * 2002 : Kiran Hebbar · Rushabh Kapashi · Anirudh Patni * 2001 : Sarin Suvarna · Venkatesh Saha * 2000 : Ashesh Badani · Saahil Mahajan * 1999 : Sujith Banerjee · Ankur Daga * 1998 : Manju Chandrasekhar · Shannon Shah * 1997 : Khawar Mann · Prashant Mehta * 1996 : Vinnie Badinehal · Anjan Malik · Vikram Limaye (Founders)

{{about|the video game|the in-car zoological park|Safari park}} {{Infobox video game |title = Wildlife Park |image =Wildlife Park Coverart.jpg |developer = [[B-Alive GmbH]] |publisher = [[Deep Silver]]
[[JoWood Productions]]
[[Encore Software Inc.]] |designer = |engine = |released = December 8, 2003 |genre = [[Construction and management simulation games|Construction and Management Sim]] |modes = [[Single player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] }} '''''Wildlife Park''''' is a [[construction and management simulation games|construction and management simulation game]] released in [[2003 in video gaming|2003]]. Like ''[[Zoo Tycoon]]'' and ''[[Zoo Empire]]'', the game involves players in building a [[wildlife park]] or [[zoo]]. The game spawned two sequels.{{Citation needed|date=April 2015}} == Reception == {{Video game reviews | MC = 62/100 }} The game received "mixed or average" reviews, according to video game [[review score aggregator]] [[Metacritic]]. ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/wildlife-park/critic-reviews |title=Wildlife Park Critic Reviews for PC |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=April 24, 2015 }} }} ==External links== *[http://www.gamespot.com/pc/strategy/wildlifepark/index.html GameSpot profile] *[http://pc.ign.com/objects/487/487565.html IGN profile] [[Category:2003 video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Germany]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]] {{simulation-videogame-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = William Doyle | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = Irish | education = [[Trinity College, Dublin]] | occupation = Businessman | years_active = | salary = | title = Chief Executive of [[Newbridge Silverware]] | term = 1993–present | predecessor = Dominic Doyle | successor = | spouse = Monica<ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Andrea|title=The jewel in Newbridge's crown|url=http://www.independent.ie/style/the-jewel-in-newbridges-crown-34240660.html|accessdate=11 April 2016|publisher=Irish Independent|date=30 December 2015}}</ref> | children = }} '''William Doyle''' is an Irish businessman and current [[Chief executive officer|chief executive]] of [[Newbridge Silverware]], a cutlery and giftware manufacturer based in [[Newbridge, County Kildare|Newbridge]], [[County Kildare]].<ref>{{cite news|title=5 minutes with William Doyle|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/5-mins-with-william-doyle-26361087.html|accessdate=11 April 2016|publisher=Irish Independent|date=21 October 2006}}</ref>
Doyle grew up in Co. Kildare and was educated at [[Newbridge College]]. He studied Business Studies and Economics at [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College Dublin]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Leadership Insight – William Doyle|url=http://www.cpaireland.ie/docs/default-source/regulation/24_leadership-insight-william-doyle.pdf?sfvrsn=4|publisher=Institute of Certified Public Accountants in Ireland (CPA Ireland)|accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref>
William Doyle took over as CEO of Newbridge Cutlery, one of Ireland's oldest brands, from his father Dominic Doyle in 1993 when he died.<ref>{{cite web|title=Celebrating 80 years of Newbridge Silverware|url=http://www.newbridgesilverware.com/news/ournews/101/80+Years|publisher=Newbridge Silverware|accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref> The company had a turnover of €27 million in 2007 and has a strong emphasis on marketing, advertising and brand awareness in both the domestic and international market.<ref>{{cite news|title=How Newbridge cornered the market in modern silverware and jewellery|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/how-newbridge-cornered-the-market-in-modern-silverware-and-jewellery-31163716.html|accessdate=11 April 2016|publisher=Irish Independent|date=23 April 2015}}</ref> Newbridge Silverware brand ambassadors have included [[Yasmin Le Bon]], [[Sophie Dahl]], [[Ronan O'Gara]], [[Rob Kearney]], [[Rozanna Purcell]], [[Amy Huberman]] and [[Naomi Campbell]], among others.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rugby player Rob Kearney models Newbridge Silverware latest collection|url=http://www.tv3.ie/xpose/article/fashion/160883/PICS-Rugby-player-Rob-Kearney-models-Newbridge-Silverware-latest-collection|accessdate=11 April 2016|publisher=Xposé|date=6 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=McQuillan|first1=Deirdre|last2=Carr|first2=Aoife|title=Naomi Campbell revealed as the new face of Newbridge Silverware|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/naomi-campbell-revealed-as-the-new-face-of-newbridge-silverware-1.2344416|accessdate=11 April 2016|publisher=The Irish Times|date=8 September 2015}}</ref>
Doyle was nominated in the 2005 [[Ernst & Young]] Entrepreneur of the Year awards.<ref>{{cite news|title=2005 Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year|url=http://presspack.rte.ie/2005/09/29/2005-ernst-young-entrepreneur-of-the-year/|accessdate=11 April 2016|publisher=RTÉ Press Centre|date=29 September 2005}}</ref>

'''Yasutaka Murata''' (村田泰隆 Murata Takashi Yasushi) was born in 1947 in [[Kyoto]] as first son of [[Akira Murata]], who three years earlier founded the company that was to become [[Murata Manufacturing|Murata Manufacturing Co., Ltd.]]
Yasutaka Murata joined Murata Manufacturing in 1973 after graduating from [[New York University]] (with a Bachelor of Science degree in Quantitative Analysis).
In 1974, he was appointed as Director of Murata Electronics Singapore.
He was assigned to be the Senior Executive Director of Fukui Murata Manufacturing in May 1979.
Mr. Yasutaka Murata became [[Vice president|Executive Vice President]] of Murata Manufacturing in 1982 and Corporate Executive Vice President seven years later. In June 1991 he became President Statutory Representative Director of Murata Manufacturing.
Since June 2007 Mr. Yasutaka Murata has been serving as [[Chairman|Chairman of the Board]] and Representative Director of Murata Manufacturing Co., Ltd. He is also Chairman of the Board and Representative Director of six subsidiaries.
== External links == *[http://www.edn.com/article/CA6346586.html A Silent Giant Speaks] An interview by Mike Green - Electronic Products News, June 23, 2006
{{Authority control}}
